title: Bluetooth Volume issue since Nougat update

thread.text:
Hi,
I am new here and was unable to find anything on this so if it has been asked please excuse the duplication. I have an S6 Edge Plus and I just recently updated to Nougat (7.0). Every since then I have not been able to adjust the Bluetooth volume when I am connect to my car stereo to use my phone. When I try to increase the volume it wont go higher than about half way (level 15 on my stereo). When I try to turn it up it automatically decreases back to the half way point. This is only when I use the phone, it does not affect the volume control for the MP3 player and it only does it in my car. I have tried volume lockers and various Bluetooth Volume controls and no luck. Has anyone else had this happen? Any ideas on how to fix it or override it?

I have this same issue -- with an S6 Edge (not the Plus). My stereo is a Kenwood (KMM-BT515HD). I plan to do a firmware update to the stereo (just noticed they released one a few months ago), but my last issue with this phone and stereo was a problem with call waiting and audio distortion (if a call came in while I was on a call, neither call was intelligible) and that actually got resolved by the Nougat update. So, I suspect this issue is a problem with the phone and not the stereo.
Oh, and I have found that if someone calls me (and I haven't initiated the call), then I can adjust the volume. I've also unpaired and removed the BT connection between the two and re-paired and no change.

I have a Kenwood stereo as well. I did find a Firmware update so I will run that too. I was able to get the volume turned up and have not touched it so it has stayed at the same level. Thanks for the reply.

PatrickMJ, I have the exact same problem. Kenwood radio...bluetooth works fine except with call volume, display won't go above level 15. You stated you were able to get the volume turned up...how did you do it???? Hope to hear from you soon.

I have the same problem with my Kenwood KDC-X5100BT and a Samsung Galaxy J5 (2016), since an update to Android Nougat 7.1.1.
The volume of calls don't go above level 15.
Any solution please????
Thanks a lot
PATRICKMJ, was the fix a firmware update on the stereo?

title: After receiving a notification, the app of the notification automatically opens.

Depending on how old the battery is it looks like it may be coming to the end of its life. What is happening is in most cases an indication of eventual battery failure.
thanks. I got this phone from Asurion in November after I filed a claim. Worked ok for a month and a half and then started to do this.

Contact Asurion and let them know what's happening with your replacement. Show them those screenshots, if necessary. They ought to send you another replacement -- and make sure they don't charge you another deductible, since they sent you a phone with either a defect or a worn-out battery.

title: S6 edge+ battery drain.

thread.text:
Hello everyone! Have only just signed up to the forum after just beeing an avid viewer as such 
Now for the reason i have signed up ha! 
I've recently bought a S6 edge+ off the internet. It works fine far as i know apart from one little issue! The battery once fully charged is draining pretty damn quick. Its fine when screen locked. But with use theirs no way it would last a full day almost. 
I've done various checks but im not fully certain on all the latest tips and tricks. Ive downloaded the GSam battery monitor. And in my eyes it looks like the biggeat issues are tbe percentage of cpu apps and phone radio the main cauae of drain. Heres a few pics. Does any of this look ab normal as such?
Not sure what this actually means. But it seems a hell of a lot. Phone on 71% now already.
Hope these have helped. Would like to know hopefully what the issue is
If you need any more pics let me know

Welcome to the forums. It seems your cell signal is very weak or even nonexistent occasionally. This will drain your battery faster than usual (phone radio percentage). Check your phone signal chart in Gsam.
It's better if you use the phone until the battery percentage is about 30-40% and then check the stats. This way they will give you more details of what's going on.
Phone on 36% when it drops to 30 ill send pic of phone radio and stats. Cheers
Phone now on 30. Hope these help?
So basically from full charge. We're talking 3 hours of usage. Any idea why?

Yeah, you cell signal is not the best and it will drain the battery a bit faster, specially when on mobile data as it seems your case. Also, check your display brightness level, try keeping it on auto and between 40-60%. This can make a big difference on the battery life. Which level did you set?
On low vs Auto and full. Thoughts? Whilst i was typing this on auto adjust it's already down 1%
Here

replies.text:
It's normal the screen showing the highest percentage, just keep the brightness on auto and low next cycle and see if it makes any difference. About the apps usage, Gsam is not very useful for this after Nougat. Better check the stock stats in settings - battery.
Also, when possible see what kind of battery life you get when connected to a WiFi network for a long time.

Yeah, that high percentage is related to the weak cell signal, specially if you are on mobile data.

thread.text: Will check tomorrow as it's currently flat lol. Will use it down till about 30% ish and check battery stats. Not too sure how to on the new android version (not stock stats anyway) But i imagine it's still u der settings- battery. Cheers for the replies today

Phone battery stats right now currently connected to wifi . Discharging normal..

If so how or can this be prevented? From the pic below the rate seems normal so not so sure the battery is faulty? Cheers.
Can't believe how much longer the battery is lasting on wifi vs Data. All though is that normal for data to drain the batteries on these phones..

replies.text:
Yeah, mobile data will hit your battery harder than WiFi and there's not much you can do about that. For example, my average is about 8+ hours SoT while on WiFi versus 6 hours on mobile data. That's the way it is.
In your case the difference is even bigger because your cell signal seems to be very poor. 
Very often I stay in places where cell signal is pretty bad and my SoT average drops by half or even more when I use the phone a lot in those conditions. Having a dual SIM phone helps me to switch between carriers depending on where I am, but the only real 'fix' is switching mobile data off and only connecting from time to time. Or keeping a charger or power bank always at hand.

title: Dust under rear camera on s6e+

thread.text: I left my phone for a couple hours. Went back on it to take a picture and noises there's a black smudge on the picture. Brother told me it's dust but I've tried everything and it won't budge. I've tried bang on it, hitting it, tapping it, dropping it, cleaning it and nothing works. Any help?

Welcome to Android Central! I moved this from the S6 edge forum to the S6 edge+ forum, just to be as specific as possible.
I'm assuming this is the case, but just to be sure -- does the same smudge show up in the same place on every shot you take? If there's dust on the inside of the camera glass, you'd probably have to get it removed and cleaned, then replaced -- I'd bring it to a repair shop for that. Be careful about hitting the area too much, since the autofocus mechanism is a moving part, and excess trauma might disrupt it.

title: Calculator error in Android 6.0.1, how can I fix it?

thread.text:
Hi
After updating to Android 6.0.1 a very simple calculation error has appeared in the built in calculator app. 
Examples:
100+10%=100.1 (110)
100-10%=99.9 (90)
100*10%=10 (1000)
100/10%=1000 (10)
Android version: 6.0.1
Mobile: Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge+
Model no: SM-G928F
Cheers 
David

10% is .1 therfore 100+0.1=100.1 How is that wrong? You are not wrong either! If you try many calculators you will find differing results. 10% onits own doesnt mean anything so i guess some assume its x% of 1 whereas others assume its the other value in the sum.

replies.text: You my friend are a stickler. I have the same problem on my Note 5. It's not a concern whether the calculator is right or not due to a decimal point, the problem is if I'm trying to take 58% out of 1000 I can do the math in my head no problem but if it's an odd number we need our calculator to go ahead and do that for us. For everybody that has this problem I downloaded another calculator that works great it's called calculator Plus and it reminds me of an old Texas instrument calculator for high school

thread.text:
I've never seen anyone attempt math like this before. Assumption is the mother of all f*** ups. 100+10%? 10% of what, there is no argument there. The calculator would almost have to assume you mean 0.1. In which case every time the answer is correct as pointed out above. 
If you really want to know the proper way to calculate this then you need to say 100*1.1, 100*.9, 100/0.1, and 100*0.1. Machines calculate quickly but are otherwise quite lacking. If you just assume it knows what you want a percentage OF then you will get the wrong answer 99.9999% of the time.
Posted via the Android Central App

Yes, technically David was doing the calculation wrong if you take into account that 10% means 10/100 or 0.1. His calculator is correct mathematically. However most hand calculators are designed for everyday people to use not mathematicians. Who ever wants to calculate a percentage addition or subtraction like described above? No one I know. Most people want to calculate % markups and such. So calculator manufacturers got smart and figured out that most people are wanting to calculate the result of one number less (or plus) a certain percentage of that same number. So instead of having to do the first step of the calculation either in their head or on a calculator as a pre calculation they added the percentage (%) button to do just that. Every other android device I have had before my galaxy s7 has. Every office calculator does it. Why have android changed? That's the real question. 
I certainly don't want to have to type in 100+(100*(10/100)) or even 100+10%*100 when I could just type in as David did and what most people do. Who gives a **** if it's not mathematically correct as typed into your calculator? Somehow I doubt anyone who cares so much about maths would be even trying to use the % button on a calculator.
EldoradoSan, you mustn't hang around many people who calculate percentages regularly. While you may not have 'seen anyone attempt math like this before' I don't know many who wouldn't. Most people worked out, or were taught, what the % button an a calculator actually does and it saved them heaps of time. Aparently Android doesn't like that convention any more and prefers instead to be inconvenient. Maybe they don't even know it's an issue.
Linds

replies.text:
Well, Linds, you're certainly right on one point. My friends and I don't sit around calculating percentages and comparing the results from our differing calculators and methods.
Here's the problem, though. There is no standard, nor will there ever likely be, for the percentage button on calculators. But I guess I'm just an oddball. I don't use a calculator to figure percentages. I'm mathematically sound enough to know all I have to do is move the little decimal point to get 10%. Because lets be honest here, there are really only a couple of reasons to even figure a percentage: finding a tip amount or how much tax we are going to pay on an item. And I'd bet most people don't even do the latter. 
So, if people want to rely on unsound methods when it comes to their money, good for them. I'm not one of those people. You can either do it the right way, or take your chances with your own way.

That would be some party.That's where I think you're wrong. I challenge you to find a calculator (not a phone app) that wouldn't give 110 when you type in 100+10%. 
I'm exactly the same when figuring out what 10% of something is. I don't have to use the % button. But it's different when adding or subtracting a percentage to a number. I'm sure most people would only do this once in a blue moon. But I do it daily. I'm in retail. I'm constantly figuring out markups and the like. I used to often use my phone to do such when I was away from my desk. But now it's just a pain in the ***. It's not so bad to do it in your head when it's adding 10% but I don't really want to do something like 56.98-23% in my head. It's not an unsound method when you know your calculator works that way. David was using the "right way" for a standard calculator. If I wanted to do everything long hand I'd use a pen and paper. After all, they were invented to make things easier. 
One soon realises when a calculator works differently like David did. We're not blindly following some random method and taking whatever pops up on the screen. We just want it to work like normal. That's why I looked this up. Obviously it's an issue for people who use the function. 
Again, why did android change from the norm?
Linds

thread.text:
Read this blog and you'll see that I'm not alone. Many calculators straight up don't even have a percent sign. Those are especially in science/math/engineering focuses like mine. https://blogs.msdn.microsoft.com/old...10-00/?p=23853
If people like it then so be it. Obviously, it doesn't work all the time, or at the very least is unreliably implemented, or this conversation would have never occurred. My method works every time and I'm satisfied to continue using it. 
The fact that people don't even know the real method, if for no other reason than as a double check, says quite a bit about society. And that is unsurprising.
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text:
True, I suppose that's because anyone using a sceintific calculator has no need or probably inclination to use that function. I wasn't very clear, I meant a run of the mill calculator you could buy at any supermarket or office supply shop. Just like the blog post was talking about. I suppose the only way the % function makes anything better is because it removes the 'in your head' part of the equation. So yes, it's unnecessary, but it is convenient. Sure, and I'm not knocking your method in the slightest. I'm just saying it's what people are used to doing with an everyday calculator and it does work every time on an every day calculator. It suits people that don't think like a mathematician. Yes, it's sad and it doesn't stop at maths. I get frustrated when people don't know how to sew or use 'to' and 'too' correctly. However, I know that I used to work out all percentage calculations without using the % button. It's just convenience and laziness. But since I learned what the % key does I've been using it because it's easier. Our brains work like that, they are inherently lazy. Kind of like picking up a calculator in the first place. I don't need it for most calculations, I'm just lazy and slow at maths. 
So since people who don't need/want a % button (like yourself) don't use it, why on earth should it have a function like what the latest version of android and windows calculators have and stuff around the people it was created for? Is it just to be an ***, or is there a real reason? If there is some reason then I'm ok with it. But like I asked in the beginning. Why would anyone want it to have the function /100? I know it's what % means in general terms but who cares?
Linds

title: How do I block emails on my Galaxy S6 Edge+

thread.text:
I want to block selected emails in the standard email client (not Gmail) on my Samsung S6 Edge+. I've read instructions directing me to click on the More Options button when I open the email App, however, there isn't any such button. 
Any help appreciated.

Go to GMail , open an email you want to block, click or tap More, click or tap "Filter messages like these", set up anything that needs to be set up (I just use the "From address), click or tap "Create filter with this search", check the Delete box, if there's a number greater than 0 in "Also apply filter to X matching conversations." and let it go. Then the emails matching the criteria on the first page will get deleted before you see them, or soon after, depending on the email app you're using. That's about the best you can do, as far as I know.

I had this problem and it traced back to IPv6 addressing. My cable modem apparently cannot interface properly with the cable internet's IPv6 assignment. What ends up happening is the phone requests an IPv6 address and the router either hands out some bogus crap or nothing based on what it thinks the cable modem is telling it. It messes up the phone's ability to talk to Google or YouTube since they have IPv6 addressing implemented. Shutting off IPv6 address assignment on my router fixed this issue.

I have the same problem in my samsung galaxy a5. After upgrading to marshmallow i can't download apps from play store and also all other google related services are not connecting through my wifi home network. But able to download through other wifi connections and mobile network. Other phones and tabs are working fine on same network. I factory restored both modem and phone but still the same problem exist. Pls tell me if anybody knows a solution.

Tell you what, guys. I came on here for the same issue, but nothing seemed right. So, I went to 'update all' manual button and got the dreaded "there's no room left" message. So checked my storage and had over 1.6Gb of cached memory, so cleared that and all 14 apps downloaded no bother. 
Just a thought, might be the issue for some of you, as the IPv6 isn't the solution for some and it certainly wasn't for me.

this might be late, but i'm just leaving this comment for those that are still experiencing this problem, disabling the IPv6 from my access point works like a charm. Hope that'll be a fix for you guys too and a big thanks to LanceAllan for the solution!

Assuming you have a screen protector installed: remove any case and wash the case with regular soap and water, use a microfiber cloth and a 50/50 solution of distilled white vinegar and water. Dampen the cloth with the solution and gently wipe all surfaces of the phone and make sure the phone case is completely dry before using on your phone. Do not use the vinegar solution on a bare screen.

A lot of devices use oleophobic coating on the glass. It is not recommended to use any alcohol-based solutions when cleaning a capacitive touchscreen, neither is it a good idea to apply common household detergents, even if it's stated that they can be used for computer and / or TV screens. The aggressive compounds in such cleaners can easily wipe off the oleophobic coat and leave your glass “naked”.
Cleaning your mobile device's glass should generally be done with just a soft, cotton rag. In extreme cases, water-based solvents should do the trick – cleaners that are specifically designed for touchscreens can be bought at various outlets, just make sure to check the ingredients, as many manufacturers will feel no remorse in stamping an alcohol-based detergent as mobile-friendly. Also, applying the detergent to the rag, rather than spraying it directly on the screen, is a good idea.

Welcome to Android Central! Charge up to 100%, then let it drain to 20-30% with normal usage, without charging in between. Then show us:
1. The main Settings>Battery screen.
2. The fullscreen battery graph screen (which shows Awake time and Cell Signal Strength).
3. The Screen category (to see total Screen On time).
4. The Cell Standby category, if present (to see Time Without Signal).http://forums.androidcentral.com/gen...d-central.html
You might have to install a 3rd party battery monitor, like GSam Battery Monitor, to get the Cell Signal Strength graph.

title: New battery and still horrible battery life even after calibrating

thread.text: I'm about to give up on this phone and just sell it. I have a galaxy s6 edge plus and i replaced it with 3 batteries so far and every one of them gives me random and horrible battery life, i did some calibrating by letting it die to 0% and then charge to 100% overnight then repeated 4 times. and still no good. I barely can use my phone normally for half the day even with power save mode on. Anyone know whats going on here? replacing the battery was hard enough taking the phone apart and now this...
First, what do your battery stats show as using the charge?

Thats weird there was no reply button earlier but there is now for some reason, but anyways, The battery stats just show a pretty much stead decline when benchmarking the same app. Also its pretty much random.
Okay, but what apps are listed as having used the charge?

Screen, phone idle, android OS, android system and audioserver. this is on a fresh factory reset, only app i tested was youtube for battery drain, played the same 10 hour long video at the same brightness and power save mode on medium. results are just random after each charge.

Assuming that you have at least a reasonably good cell signal, and that the battery performance is much the same when using wifi, I'm guessing that there may be a fault with the phone, but I'll move the thread to the S6 Edge Plus forum for comments from other users.

What you did - charge/discharge 4 times (usually 3 times is enough) isn't recalibrating anything, it's conditioning the battery. You do that to a new phone (or battery) in case the battery has been sitting on a shelf for months.
To recalibrate, you can use Battery Calibration (Root), but the phone has to be rooted to recalibrate the battery (the app has to change the system file that holds the voltage of the fully charged battery).

Well i figured out the issue! I decided to take the circuitboard out and inspect the connection of the daughterboard was so loose the connector just fell right off when moving the board, i snapped it back on there securely and now im getting the correct battery life! so all the issues was just a short between the connectors all this time, I am so relieved. thank you guys for the help.

title: Receiving Text notifications from 1 person, but no actual text is there. Why?

No, but they could be "pocket dialing" in some way that sends texts. If the numbers and letters you see aren't your ex's phone number, it could be an automated texting service trying to sell you something (just put that number in your phone's ignore list) or it could be a virus. It's not possible to get any closer to the actual cause this way - someone who knows how to find out has to have the phone in his or her hands.

title: Retrieve contacts from Google acct

thread.text:
Hi All,
Please bear with me...
I did my first factory reset today.
Beforehand, I carefully followed instructions on how to back up EVERYTHING to my Google and Google+ accts
I performed the reset, added my google acct, my android (samsung galaxy 6 mega) said that it connected the acct, but I virtually have none of the backed up stuff on my android. No music, no apps, ONLY 28 OUT OF 200 CONTACTS. The Calendar is synced, but that's about all I see.
I'm up sh^t's creek without a paddle.
I desperately need help. It's a business phone.
Sincerely,
Tutor

If you go to http://contacts.google.com and sign in with your account, do you see all your contacts there?
App DATA unfortunately doesn't sync with Google (unless the app supports cloud saves). Yes, it keeps a list of apps you've installed and helps re-install the same apps upon reset, but the data, if saved to the device, is lost unless backed up with a different method (Google is, after all, cloud-centric).

I only see 2 contacts on that link, but 28 were restored.
I'm not sure what cloud centric means,; but if Google doesn't have my contact's (after I followed the instructions to the letter),; then I'm just at a loss for words

I only see 2 contacts on that link, but 28 were restored.
I'm not sure what cloud centric means,; but if Google doesn't have my contact's (after I followed the instructions to the letter),; then I'm just at a loss for words.
I mean it took forever to backup my texts, so they had to go somewhere

How did you back them up? If you only see two contacts on the Contacts page, those are the only ones actually synced to Google. The other contacts might have been stored in your SIM Card or, depending on how you did your backup, on that specific service.

I found a way to fix the issue. 
I went into all applications in settings and uninstalled the Samsung pay application. After uninstalling the app all my credit cards were removed from my account. I had the same problem too, but i've found a way to fix it.
1. Go to setting>apps>search for samsung pay
2. On the top right you will see an option, tap on it and proceed with "uninstall updates"
3. Reinstall and it will ask you to update the apps. Update it.
4. Proceed as usual. Done.

I'm usually at least 4 to 5 . By the way every OS is different my lumia 1520 will outlast most big phones almost 2 days but android uses a little more juice 
Posted via the Android Central App

Thanks. I spilt my coffee reading that! (Although you did ask how to get longer battery life)
So, first off, it's not an iPhone. iPhones go all day and all night and even the next day without a charge, so forget about your previous iPhone experiences. This is an Android phone that requires finesse and some degree of tweaking in order to get half the life of an iPhone. Out of the box, most iPhone users will experience a significant decrease in battery life, so try out the ideas other Android users have tried and see if they work for you. If you don't want to, then carry an extra charging cable or an external battery backup with you. I carry both and I have a Qi charger on my desk where my phone sits all day.
Good Luck

thread.text:
I would tweak Facebook settings if I were you. There's absolutely no reason Facebook should ever use more power than the screen itself. You can turn off Facebook auto-refresh in the background which is probably what's eating up your battery. It refreshes your News Feed as soon as you open up the app, there's no reason to have it refreshing in the background when your phone is locked.
That's pretty much the only thing I can think of, otherwise everything else seems normal. GPS is a real battery killer, and the battery on the Edge+ is... well, it's no iPhone 6 plus let's put it that way. Apple runs a very tight ship when it comes to background tasks, in exchange for Android's customization you get optimization.

replies.text: Thanks for the suggestions, but how do I do this? I don't the see the setting in the Facebook App or Messenger App to restrict background activity.

Go to your phone settings > Connections > Data Usage > Background Data
Here you will see a list of pretty much all your installed apps and each has a toggle of whether they should be allowed to be connected in the background or not. Simply toggle the ones you don't want running in the background. I would recommend toggling off Facebook but not Facebook messenger (if you use it actively) as messengers and email services do require background data in order to receive push notifications.
Like others have said here, typical users can get between 4 to 5 hours of on screen time, 2ish is very low in comparison. I myself have been able to squeeze out almost 6 hours of on screen time but this does not include GPS navigation. GPS is a real battery drainer when left unchecked, even if you're not using maps, a lot of apps like to use GPS in the background, I would check which apps have been using your location services as well if I were you. For me, I just toggle GPS off from my notification toggles unless I actually need to use navigation.

thread.text:
The biggest issue for me is WiFi. If I have a full charge, clear ram,close all apps and then leave overnight it typically loses between 20% to 30% in around 8.5 hrs which is woeful. However, after reading up on various issues around this I tried turning WiFi off last night at 100% full charge and left overnight again. This morning it had only dropped 3% which I felt was exceptional. During the day I typically get at least 3.5 hrs on screen time, sometimes past 4 but it really depends on so many factors what you are doing with that screen on time, e.g taking photos, editing photos, maps, browsing, gaming, Facebook uploads, calls, quality of connection at any time, how bright screen is etc etc. My WiFi issue is annoying though. Luckily I have enough mobile gb per month not to worry too much. Anyone have a fix for this?
jinzen - is your WiFi typically left on all the time?

replies.text:
Does your WiFi support both 2.4G and 5G? If so, test it out on one or the other. I don't have any issues with WiFi on my Edge+ currently but I have had experiences in the past (with this phone and other phones) where sometimes one of the bands are unfriendly towards the battery. When this happens then I just switch bands for a time, the issue usually corrects itself after a day or 2.
I'm inclined to believe this isn't the phone's fault so much as a compatibility issue with the modem but I'm not technically knowledgeable enough to be sure. This has happened to me using a variety of phones and a variety of modems. It's not very common, but it's not uncommon either.

That sounds like it's either a router polling issue or you may have apps that like to frequently update or sync Data while on wifi i.e. When Google play store or Google Drive likes to sync and update files.

title: Data transfer

thread.text: Does anyone know how to transfer data from LG v20 to Samsung Galaxy s6 edge plus? I've tried the nfc and beam thing. Didn't work. Tried by using USB cord didn't work. Starting to get irritated

You should be able to do that with the Smart Switch app. Just download on each device and follow the on-screen instructions (you WILL need an OTG USB Cable/adapter if you want to use USB, though).
If you just want to send some files, then select the files/pictures/media/whatever on your V20 and select SHARE, then either via Bluetooth or WiFi Direct (don't forget to set the S6 to be visible to the V20 if they haven't been paired before). If you want to do this over USB, you need the OTB cable/adapter so that the S6 sees the V20 as an external storage device. 
The Beam function also works, but you need the S6's NFC to be turned on and Android Beam active in the NFC Settings of your phone (you can long-press the NFC toggle to go to those settings directly).

title: Why is my Galaxy S6 Edge Plus's Battery Drain Excessive?

thread.text: Hello, I have been an Apple user the last few years and have generally experienced good battery life without having to turn off a bunch of things that are useful for a smart phone. However, I have had this new phone for a few weeks now, and I am not impressed with the battery life. For everybodys' information, I have AT&T. I have had battery saver mode constantly on. I have disabled various wifi issues (always scanning, smart network switch, enhanced services) and it seems to still be a problem. I will post pictures of my battery usage data.

That looks like a reasonable run, you have an amazing powerful device with a super bright screen! Marshmallow is a bit kinder to battery life, and the S7 is better still! It also depends on how solid the network signal is in your area... I have an external battery pack on mine and it goes forever....

How much total Uptime did you get on your iPhone?
If it's both 14 hours, I'd say there's nothing to worry about.
Remember, iPhone "Usage" figures and Android Screen On time aren't the same. You can't calculate Screen on Time on iPhone unless you're literally using it non-stop.
Thanks for the replies. I don't remember what my total uptime was that day. Ill keep an eye out for that. If it looks normal, I guess I just need to get used to it! Thanks again

This may or may not be your problem, but I'll relate this because I've had two separate instances of my GS6 Edge+'s battery going down more quickly than normal (and the phone heating up more), and both were due to the system app "Media Storage" acting up.
I found the fix on Google once I saw that something called mediaserver was using a lot of juice. I see in your second screen shot that Media Server is using 4%. I don't recall if that's ok or high (mine is only using a very reasonable 0.8% after a recent "cleaning").
To fix a runaway mediaserver in Marshmallow, go into Settings --> Applications --> Applications manager, tap "More" and select "Show system apps". Find app "Media Storage" and tap on "Storage", clear cache and clear data, Force Stop the app, and you're good to go (media knowledge will eventually be rebuilt by Android). IIRC, it has something to do with media server being confused and constantly building its database.

Please get yourself a mini external battery power pack. Monster makes a good one, also keep a car charger in car at all times. I still have the s6 edge plus and wouldn't trade my phone unless it just dies completely. The Ms's has the S7 edge, she does a little better but doesn't need to attach to a charger as often as I do. I had some of the other manufacturers cell phones at one time or another and Samsung just does it better, [as in the total experience]. 
I'm no tech, guy but I think its all in Touch wiz where sams battery issues are a problem since most other manufacturers uses stock android. Suggestion, adjust your screen time on to a minimum if that helps. This was my issue, so I cut it down to 50% during the day, and at night to 20%. Find a happy spot and see how you do. Just a suggestion that's all.

thread.text: I have that problem too. I do not know how to fix it. I'm using the Samsung Galaxy S6.

Hey!
This problem was happening to a friend of mine since yesterday when we were able to find the root cause.
I'm not sure its the same for you, but you could give it a try!
He uses a "Game Tuner" application from Samsung, and when he selects a custom profile and open any game, the phone starts to behave like yours, even after he closes the game... the solution for now is to use a built-in profile like "High Performance" or "Power Saving".
Another thing that you could try is to force close the "Game Optimizing Service" application.
Go to Settings -> Application Manager -> Game Optimizing Service -> Force Stop.
I hope it helps!

replies.text:

Force closing "Game Optimizing Service" and resetting "Game Tuner" to their defaults solved the problem!

Thanks again!

I'm glad that I could help you guys! 
You're right! We sent an email about the bug to Game Tuner team three days ago. They fixed it and released the new version yesterday.
So hopefully everybody can use custom profiles again without turning the screen off!!

title: Is this a normal SOT?

thread.text:
Hey guys, I have a verizon galaxy s6 edge plus on 6.0.1 marshmallow. I have been fighting battery the whole time I owned this phone. I recently saw some other Edge +'s getting around 5 hours of SOT when I barely manage 2. do I have a defective phone possibly?
Thanks
No one??

Welcome to Android Central! Only knowing the screen-on time isn't enough to make a determination. There are many factors that can contribute to battery drain.
Charge up to 100%, then let it drain to 20-30% with normal usage, without charging in between. Then show us:
1. The main Settings>Battery screen.
2. The fullscreen battery graph screen (which shows Awake time and Cell Signal Strength).
3. The Screen category (to see total Screen On time).
4. The Cell Standby category, if present (to see Time Without Signal).http://forums.androidcentral.com/gen...d-central.html
You might have to install a 3rd party battery monitor, like GSam Battery Monitor, to get the Cell Signal Strength graph.
Remember that this is an independent community forum, so responses don't always happen right away. Give it at least a day or so for someone to reply. If you don't get a reply, you can always "bump" your thread (but not more than once per 24 hrs). Thanks!
Alright will do tomorrow. Today I managed 2:15 hours but I still hear my friends using note 5's getting 5+. It's just odd that they run the same hardware but mine is so bad
I can't figure out how to post the pictures in this thread. I have them ready
Did you try the link to my guide in my previous post? If it's not letting you post the images, you might have to get 10 posts under your belt first.
finally. there they are

Cell standby is proportionately high, and the current cell signal at the time of the screenshots was fairly poor. If it's like that for much of the battery charge, that could contribute to battery drain. Since Samsung phones generally don't include a cell signal strength indicator in the battery stats (from what I've seen on the forums), you could install GSam Battery Monitor to get that information.
I already have it installed. What do i need to do?
There's a battery graph that also shows cell signal strength -- show us that (after charging up to 100% and then using it normally down to 20-30%).

Oh okay, I forgot I did a factory reset and never installed it. I'll have to charge it back up. However, over a 4 hour period, it's only consumed 31 mAh and had a total connection time of 19 seconds I've had 1-3 bars all morning thus far
Here it is

As suspected, cell signal strength, is mostly middling to poor, so that's probably a big reason why you're seeing the battery life that you do. If you're able to use the phone in an area with good signal for a whole charge cycle, that would be an interesting comparison. Or you could try using the phone on Airplane Mode for a whole cycle, but I'm not sure how feasible that is.
I can try. Would leaving it in airplane mode with wifi on help at all?

If battery life was dramatically better, then it would strongly suggest a cell signal issue. (Battery life is better anyway on Airplane Mode, but the improvement wouldn't be as great if you had good cell signal to begin with.)
I have also noticed my cell status in the status bar is still active when wifi is on?? Is that contributing too?

The cell reception refers to your voice signal as well. If the cell signal is poor, that can still impact battery even with wi-fi on, because the phone is still trying to latch onto the cell signal for calls. If I know I'm going to be in an area of very poor cell reception for a while that also has wi-fi, I'll turn on Airplane Mode, and then turn on wi-fi after that.
mine too having same issue.very poor screen on time

Please check if this screen on time is normal or not? The screen was on continuously from 100% to 15% on 50% brightness and on default settings with power saver mode OFF. Please comment on this. Thanks

replies.text: 5-6 hours is usually the sweet spot for stock batteries. Your battery is performing very well.

title: Best case + screen protector combo?

thread.text: Hey guys. Just ordered an S6 edge plus and now I want to get a protective case and screen protector. There aren't that many drop test videos out there for cases and none for screen protectors. What are you using that's protecting your phone without losing functinality of the screen? Would love some advice. My S4 was never a fragile phone and besides a few bits of chiped paint it never had problems with just a screen foil and a flip case, but the s6 edge plus seems super frigile. Thanks!

Theoretical best case is a protector made of transparent armorplate or a sheet of diamond.
Practical best case is one of those 3/$5 plastic protectors.
Forget about protecting the screen from being dropped on the screen - nothing but steel will do that. Plastic has a bit of cushioning effect, and will give you a tiny bit of protection.
Tempered glass? If it's applied properly, a sharp object will penetrate the protector, the touchscreen and the LED screen under it, and you'll need a new screen. The only advantage of tempered glass (it's the same hardness as Gorilla Glass 3, slightly less hard than Gorilla Glass 4) is that it won't break into shards, it'll crumble, so you won't slice your hand up. If the touchscreen is applied properly, it will also break - but the tempered glass will break the shards into much smaller pieces, so it gives you some protection against cuts.
Mr. Scott, where's that transparent aluminum?

title: Galaxy S6 edge+ copy/paste not working and emojis gone.

thread.text:
(FIX) 
I have found a fix.
You don't have to lose anything or factory rest your phone, I'm not sure which method I used that worked so do all of the following.
First go to "settings" "applications" "application manager" tap "more" in the top right, then select "show system apps" first find the keyboard you are using and tap on it for example I had been using the Samsung keyboard and my emojis were the first to go so find "Samsung keyboard" go into "storage" and tap "clear data" don't worry it will not mess anything up.
Go back to the top of the applications list and you should see "AASAASservice" I then tapped it and went into the storage and tapped "clear cache" next go back and find "android system" go to "storage" and tap "clear cache" on that as well then find "Web view" and clear the cache on that. One of them fixes the issue. I now have the full copy and paste issue fixed and I have my emojis back on my keyboard!
I hope this helps everyone!
Thanks for the info! Thread moved from the Marshmallow forum to the S6 edge+ forum, since this is likely a device-specific issue, rather than a general Marshmallow issue.

title: Charging notification on repeat

thread.text:
::begin rant:: I've tried for the past few months to still love my phone. I was super excited about it when I first got it back in Aug 2015. Then the S7 Edge was released, and effectively killed what the S6 Edge + was supposed to be. Why Samsung released what was basically the successor for the phone six months after its release, still irks me to no end. All of my friends switched to the S7 edge and I was stuck with my S6 Edge + without its always on display and lack of water proofing. But, I kept on, enjoyed the extra screen real estate, and once it got 6.0, all was fine with the world. 
Until a couple of weeks ago. I noticed some of my chargers weren't working like they were supposed to; wobbling to and fro, skipping in and out of charging, and not charging as quickly as they once had. I'd switch the cable, and it'd work as it was supposed to. Weird, but whatever. Then the cables I switched started doing the same. Definitely odd. There was no stress placed on the cables while plugged in (and most of the time when I charged, it was via wireless charging while I slept). Then tonight all heck broke loose. I placed my phone on the wireless charger as usual, but instead of going to bed, I went back to my living room to watch some TV. I kept hearing a beeping noise, I couldn't place. Mute the TV, hear it faintly, but then it stopped. Repeat. Finally figured it was my phone making the "now charging" beeps over and over again. I figured I had just not placed it centered on the dock and went to reposition. This is where I figured out I was in for a night full of aggravation. I took the phone off the wireless charger, and it kept beeping! >.< 
So now I have to go tomorrow (luckily a day off work) and see if VZW will replace it, but I'll likely still have to pay the $100 deductible or whatever they wish to call it. Or try to go to a local "repair" shop to see if they can fix the charging port. OR pay off the remaining balance ($400) and try to trade it in on a new phone. I'm over it. I want a new phone. I don't want to sink any more money into this phone than I have to. I'm highly disappointed that I have been so let down by a phone that I shouldn't be having any problems with (it's a $900 phone that I've had for little over a year, always in a case, with a screen protector). Seriously thinking about a Pixel XL, even tho it's kinda ugly. /rant
tl:dr > Phone charging port is messing up and constantly giving me the charging beep notification over and over. it's annoying and I'm over this phone. But I still owe on the payment plan.

title: Can't save a download on Galaxy S6 edge+

thread.text: I can download apps just fine from the play store. But when I try to download anything ( and I mean ANYTHING) else it won't do it. I click on the link. The box comes up with the name of the file. Then the option to cancel or save. I hit save and...nothing! No error message, just nothing. This is with any file. PDF, music, etc. I've tried clearing the cache, cookies, browsing data. I've checked for duplicate files and memory usage. I cleared cache/data then forced stop on the download manager and checked the "allow downloads from unknown sources". Ive done everything but a factory reset which I REALLY don't want to do! Please help!
Welcome to Android Central! This is only when trying to download files using the browser? Can you try a different browser?

replies.text: Oh for crap sake! I was using Opera. Tried Chrome and got an error message (Opera didn't give any message) about storage permissions and turning off app overlay. I had to uninstal CM security before I could allow storage permission. Literally the ONLY reason I stay with those guys is for their caller I D and blocking feature! Thank you for making me think. I seriously appreciate it!

title: no reaction

thread.text: 3 days ago I connected the phone to the charger. the phone is turned off and since then does not want to enable.does not respond to a hard reset and the charger. computer also does not recognize it when connected

There are a few possibilities, but I suspect that the charging port (the thing you plug the charger into in the phone) is bad. The battery, after 3 days of not actually charging, is as dead as it was 3 days ago. The port would have to be replaced. (The part is cheap, usually under $10. The labor isn't. And please don't do it yourself - you'll cause damage that will cost a LOT more to fix than it costs to have someone replace the port.)
Or the entire ROM - Android, recovery and download - somehow got wiped, so there's no software in the phone. Hardware doesn't "do" anything but draw current and create a little heat - it's the software (the ROM in this case) - that makes it work.
(There are other possibilities - from the small explanation you gave us, that's about the best we can do here. You'll have to give the phone to someone who knows enough to figure out the problem.)

title: How to merge phone music app and Google music.

thread.text: I can't figure out why Amazon music automatically goes to my music app but Google play music does not. What do I do?

Amazon Music is downloaded as an MP3, whereas Google Play offline tracks are downloaded in an encrypted format specific to Google Play Music. If you want your Google Music files to show up in the stock player, you need to download the music in MP3 format, which can only be done through the Google Play Music webpage (and, obviously, only available for personal and purchased music).

replies.text:
Never assume when it comes to your phone acting up. It could be a rough app, or it could be a hot phone, or some other problem. If you take it in, they'll want you to FDR it. I say go ahead and bite the bullet and perform an FDR, after you back everything up of course. If it still hang/freezes, you'll know the phone's bad and you need it replaced. At this point, it's easy because you've already reset it.
If, however, it runs without a glitch, then you'll know it was a rough app. That means you'll have to reinstall each app testing the phone to make sure it doesn't lock up, then install the next app. The entire process could take days or even weeks to figure out which app it is, if it's an app.
Good luck.

title: phone automatically "rejects" unavailable, private or restricted calls. Goes straight to voicemail

thread.text:
For some reason, whenever I receive a call marked unavailable, private or restricted, the phone does not ring. Instead it "beeps" and the call goes automatically into voice mail. I have had the phone since December and all of a sudden it started doing this. I have not enabled blocking these types of calls via the phone's "block anonymous calls". I also have not enabled call blocking through the verizon wireless website. when i look in the phone's call log it has an icon with a blue circle with a diagonal line in it and says call was "rejected" (which I did not do.)
This started happening about a week ago. I called VZW's tech support and we did a series of tests. Finally, when the phone was put into safe mode, I was able to receive those types of calls. So the tech suggested I perform a factory reset - which I did last week. This seemed to clear up the problem. Then this morning, I started having the same issue with those type of calls going directly to voicemail and the phone beeps instead of ringing.
Anybody else have this sort of situation?
Anybody have any solutions as to how to remedy this situation? I cannot keep performing factory resets on a weekly basis.
thanks,
~ Sabrina

replies.text:
Hi Sabrina:
I don't have a definite answer for you, but in my experience, if something works in safe mode, but not in normal mode, the issue is being caused by an app that may or may not seem in any way related.
This shouldn't happen, but it does. I can't use my Microsoft Band 2 on my Nexus 6P because the Microsoft Health app stops my phone from being able to pair with anything else Bluetooth wise, and I discovered this by booting into safe mode, finding that Bluetooth pairing worked fine, then looking at the most recent apps I had installed and trying to uninstall one by one until it worked again.
So my question for you is - after you did the hard reset, did you recover back to your phone with all of the apps you had on it before? If so, it's likely an app. So go to the Google Play Store on your phone, and select My Apps. You'll see them in the order of last updated and then last installed.
See if any of them may be more obviously connected to your phone. Anything with caller ID like Sync.me, or Google Voice or even some antivirus software that has that as an addon would be the first place I'd look.
Best of luck.
Tamir
Posted via the Android Central App

I uninstalled the White Pages ID app from my phone. I used my computer's Gmail "make a call feature". through this feature you can make calls to US numbers. The numbers show up as "unavailable or private". Well the calls were ringing like they should. I hope this fixes the solution. I will miss White Pages ID. Thanks for the help

thread.text: Do you have a note 5? If so I was having the same issue...I went to the phone icon on my note 5...Selected more in the top right corner...From there you will see "Block anonymous calls" you need to turn that off...Just swipe left and it will turn that feature off

title: No metadata over bluetooth

thread.text: Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge+ using Android v 6.0.1. and the very latest version of Spotify For some reason the track and artist information is not getting `pushed` to the car stereo (Lexus IS 300h 2014 model) despite the tracks being played correctly. The very first track I play via Spotify on selection (downloaded or streamed) gets displayed correctly, also if I use the car`s forward track or back track button then it will pick this information up, but after that, it will not update/refresh with each following track. If I use the phone to play music I have loaded from the internal phone storage then the tracks metadata gets updated correctly. I have performed a clean install of spotify and checked all settings. I am also a member of Amazon Prime and used Amazon music to see if I encountered the same issue and I have. So I am lost as to whether this is a problem with Samsung/Android. It used to work a short while back but stopped working recently. I`ve tried unpairing and re-pairing the device but still the problem persists. Can anyone else confirm if they are experiencing the same problem mentioned above? Thanks.
Mod Note, I will move this to the s6ep forum for more visibility
Was this ever resolved. I had the same issue with a S5 and MB Comad. I just upgraded to S7 and still have the same issue.

Bluetooth specifies HOW to get data from one device to another - it doesn't specify WHAT data to send (yet), so if you have a phone and car that work correctly together, be glad. Usually even a minor update to the phone stops Bluetooth from working as well.
Some day, Bluetooth will be a full spec (or we'll call the full spec something else - at one time there was no way to send a picture from one carrier to another, because there was no specified way of doing it that all carriers followed) and all Bluetooth devices will work together. But we're years from that - at least.

TheLittleLeto
Since it's still an AT&T phone (you'd have to modify Android to change that) you'll get your updates from AT&T.

I've heard that I will need to debrand the phone completely and use the stock Android so that I can get OTA by Android, is that correct? If so, let me know how to do it, I really am fed up with AT&T and their OTA, they taking years to upgrade the OS from Lollipop to Marshmallow
You would have to root your phone.

But, will root give official unbranded OTAs? Debranding do not void warranty that's for sure as I have debranded S6 Edge but I am unsure how to put on stock android/rom than AT&T ones for s6 edge plus

Hi - Did you learn how to do this - exactly what Im looking to do?
Cheers,
Simon

If you reflash the phone's ROM with another one, you won't get ROM updates at all (unless the ROM's developer updates his ROM). If you want to uninstall apps, and you know which ones not to uninstall, go ahead. But even rooting the ROM (so you can remove unwanted system apps) will prevent it from updating. (The update has no idea why the ROM in the phone isn't the same as the ROM it was designed for, so it stops after a time - without having done any updating - and gives you an error message.)

title: How to recover lost photos/root?

thread.text:
Hi everyone!
My boyfriend has the s6 edge plus and accidently deleted his whole camera roll. 😑 is there any way to recover these photos? I hear its possible if the phone is rooted..is this true? If so, could someone walk me through the rooting process?
Thanks so much!

1. The process of rooting your phone wipes all data; this is a necessary security precaution - otherwise anyone who found your phone could simply root it and then have access to your most precious stuff. So, for file recovery tools to work at all, you need to root your phone *before* you need it, not after.
2. Even then, recovery of deleted files is a very iffy proposition and the more you use the phone between the time you deleted files and the time you try to recover them, the less likely you are to be successful.
Sorry, but the news is not good.
On the other hand, if he set up his phone correctly, he may find that his photos were backed up to the cloud, either at photos.google.com or at Samsung's cloud which, honestly, I don't know how to access since I haven't owned a Samsung device in years.

title: Mercedes 2017 E300 Having issues with NFC wireless charging pad for my Galaxy S6 Edge+

thread.text:
I just got a 2017 Mercedes E300 4matic and was excited to use its new features, including the NFC wireless charging pad.
The problem is, the first time I placed my phone (Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge+) onto the charging pad, it charged for about 5 seconds before it stopped charging with the message "Wireless charging paused." The charging then restarts, and after a few seconds pauses again. This cycle is nonstop until I remove the phone from the charging pad.
My phone has charged without issue on other wireless charging pads (like the ones they have at the counters at Starbucks, for example).
I looked through several online Samsung forums to figure out if it was my phone...it does seem that some Samsung phones of the current generation have issues with wireless charging and several "Fixes," so I tried them all -
Activate NFC on your phone...
Put your phone into Daydream/Screensaver mode, so the screen stays on while charging...
Place something between your phone and charger in case it is too close...
Remove the phone case (my phone doesn't have a case)...
Put the phone into Battery saving or Ultra battery saving mode...
Turn off your phone and charge it that way (which isn't ideal at all)...
Wipe the phone cache...
Restart the phone, including "Safe mode"
Some people have suggested the the amperage output from the charging pad may not be sufficient for my phone...
I even spoke with Samsung Customer Service who suggested maybe I should go to the Verizon store and have them factory reset my phone (which other people have said didn't work)...
I contacted the dealership and they are "looking into it," but I'm not expecting a real solution from them. The Mercedes Operator's Manual mentions pressing on the car's NFC logo to activate the NFC charging (the logo in the car is simply that - an NFC insignia - no button, no indication from the car that anything has been pressed or touched that I can see after I touch the logo).
This was one of the features I was looking forward to using because it's one of the things that sets the new car apart from the previous generations. Honestly, it's been pretty frustrating. I was wondering if any Samsung owners may have had any similar issues that they were able to fix?

replies.text: I have the same problem. I have gone to verizon and tried other samsung galaxy models, including the s7, which all work, so I am concluding the glitch is specific to this phone model and I am going to upgrade to the new note7. If anyone has any new fixes, post them asap. I have tried all the ones in this post.

Tried different wall plugs but still the same thing until i decided to change the cable, that did the trick.. shame on the cable thats less than 1 month old compared to the one im using now which is a year old..

Here is an excellent article about charging android phones Android USB Charging Secrets - APC
I purchased a tester and found that chargers, cables and USB ports all change the amperage that goes intot he phone. As well there is a signal that goes over the data portion of the cable.
Here are some of my findings:
1) cable wire is a big deal. 28/24 is the best (heaviest gauge). The ones you buy in the gas stations and Walgreen's are thinner and may not allow the power needed for faster charging
2) two identical HTC M9 chargers (longer body) One charged at 1.05 ma and the other at .95 ma. same outlet. Phone (HTC One M9) stated "(AC) charging" 
3) EverReady Energizer 2 AA batteries phone stated "(AC) charging" @ .43 ma
4) Fully charged 2400 ma rechargeable charger w/ cheap short cable would not charge for more that 3 minutes phone stated (USB) charging. Message = "phone using too much power cannot charge"
5) Fully charged 2400 ma rechargeable charger w/ good cable = "(AC) charging" @ .25 ma
6) Best results! USB 3 computer port. "(AC) charging" @ 1.45 ma
7) Cigarette car charger w/ good cable (USB) charging" @ .45 ma
8) Car USB port w/ good charger (USB) charging @ .95 ma
There is a handshake between phone and charger and it depends on the cable data port voltage and message that controls amperage. Some phone and charger manufacturers ahve set up proprietary handshakes to get faster charging!

title: My Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge factory reset itself. How? Why?

thread.text: My Samsung Galaxy 6 Edge+ did a factory reset all on its own three weeks ago. I wasn't touching or evening using it. Initially I wasn't too devastated because I knew that I had my phone set up to have all pictures and videos backed up to Google Drive. You can imagine my surprise when I logged in to Google Drive only to discover that none of my pictures and videos were there. In fact, it appears that nothing has been saving from before the day that I activated this phone (Sept. 13th). Over two months of data cannot be found. I find that to be so strange, because when I periodically checked, I saw my pictures in Google Drive. Chats with Verizon, Google, and Samsung reps have been useless. A Verizon rep even told me that this has happened to all sorts of devices and there is 'no rhyme or reason for it'. She assured me that she's never seen it happen to a phone twice. That's comforting. After searching online, I noticed that others who have experienced this have blamed the recent software update for causing the reset. I'm curious whether another else has experienced this. The consensus is that my data is lost forever and there's 'no way' to retrieve it. A friend even tried to use some recovery software but that didn't work. If someone has a suggestion for what to try, I'm all ears.

title: Is my phone water damaged?

thread.text:
My phone got wet on Monday morning. I put the phone in rice and completely charged it. When I turned the phone back on several things happened. 
1. I got the error message the fingerprint sensor is not responding. Try again later.
2. The date and time was not correct so I updated manually.
3. The phone will not connect to my data network. 
4. Camera fails. 
I'm putting it back in rice but is there any troubleshooting for these issues or is my phone damaged?
This pretty seems to be the problem with software so try flashing the firmware, If the problem persists kindly take it to the customer care.

I would not try re-flashing the software. I would take it immediately to a professional for repair. Continuing to power up if water is still on the circuits....could cause electrical shock, and or permanently damage your phone.
Hope this helps!

title: Watch videos from my phone on TV

thread.text: Hi, I'll be traveling on a motorhome with my family for many hours, and would like to be able to stream Netflix, etc from my phone and watch on the TV. It's a few years old TV, I believe Panasonic brand so not Samsung brand. My phone is Galaxy S6 Edge Plus. I've been searching for how to do this but I've read there is no MHL option or HDMI cable connection option for the S6. Chromecast really isn't an option because we'll be driving down the highway and will rely on my mobile network. Any suggestions please on how I could make this work? Also please I'm not tech savvy so be patient with me. Thanks so much for any advice!!
Mod Note, I will move this to the s6ep forum for more visibility

I'm not sure this meets your requirements for moving in a vehicle, because I'm pretty much a novice in TV connectivity myself. But this was recommended by some posters as an easy way to get an S6 Edge+ mirrored on a TV with an HDMI port. Sound goes to the TV, and gets muted on the phone:
- Actiontec ScreenBeam Mini 2 - plugs into HDMI port, plus it needs USB power, which I get from my TV's USB port, using the included USB extension cord.
- ScreenBeam Utility app - allows you to update the Mini 2's firmware, and also make config changes (I changed nothing, just used the defaults).
- (optional) Miracast Widget & Shortcut - Use this to connect quickly. For some reason, I could not connect after the first time using the standard way (Swipe down --> down arrow on upper right --> EDIT upper right just to the left of up arrow --> Smart View). So now I always use this widget to connect, making for just a few steps (Switch TV input to that HDMI port, power the Mini 2, TV screen says "ready to connect" or similar, then I tap this widget et voila, a mirrored phone, which plays video flawlessly in my few tests.
Unfortunately, I don't recall whether I initially connected using Samsung's Quick Connect or not. I've only used this setup a couple of times at a beach house, and I'm not there now to test and learn better how it all works (Quick Connect vs. EDIT/Smart View vs. Miracast widget).

title: S6 edge + worth upgrade?

thread.text:
Currently I have the GS5 on T-Mobile right now. I have been looking at the S6 Edge Plus for awhile now. They currently have a promotion where you can save 200 dollars instantly. I was thinking about jumping ship and purchasing it. Is it a worth while upgrade though from my S5? One negative definitely for me is my S5 being water resistant and the S6E+ not being at all. But, it would definitely be awesome having a larger screen with the speaker actually on the bottom. The 32GB is 479.99 and the 64GB is 499.99.
Does the the curved edge features of the phone get old after awhile?
Get it....i would definitely make the upgrade if I were you!

I honestly have not used either edge in months and have even disabled it just so I don't accidentally swipe it.
The dual edges are purely for looks ....... for me anyways.

I use the edge all the time, mostly as a hidden dock for my mostly used apps. I rarely have to open the app drawer, and my home screen is empty except for the weather/clock widget. That being said, the price is $499 before the credit? If so, and you really want it, go for it. If not, I would hold off until the S7 edge drops in price. It does have some features such as always on display, SD card expansion, and the water resistance that you're looking for that the edge + doesn't have. Samsung kinda burned everyone w/ the edge+ by releasing the next iteration only 6 months after the S6 edge+ release. Updates are getting better (at least through VZW), so we at least have most of the actual software features of the S7 edge.

I prefer my s6 edge plus to the s7 edge, on account of the s6e+ having 7% more screen area.

title: 32GB or 64GB, which one are you rockin and Why?

thread.text:
Hey folks
Just been getting my 32GB Gold +, and I love it.. its great under MM.
I am Just curious to know which GB do you have and Why did you choose it. 
I came from a Lumia 1520 and a G4, both had SDCards and I found that i just threw anything on there, including music i never listened too, Kindle books and Docs i didnt read and wouldnt bother removing apps I had tried out..
For me, I find now-a-days I use less space.. I also find that having 32gb Im actually more careful about what I put on it and only include what I need, rather than because the space is there.. ie, choosing the music i put on and ripping music in 256 or 320k MP3 instead of Flac or WMA..
I find its better house cleaning and i run into less battery or lag problems doing that, and of course, internal ram is Much faster for read / write.
Obviously shooting alot of HD video, yes.. a 64GB is needed, but how about general day to day usage
So what about you folk, can you get away with 32GB
I went for the 64gb gold, main reason I keep my song's, photos, sat nav and other apps without worrying and also for a better resale value.
64gb, because there wasn't a 128gb option.

Sadly in UK, the 64gb is really hard to get hold of, you have to order one ...and costs more on contract, even now, Main reason for me is that, first I dont shoot alot of HD video and When it came down to it.... I was just putting everything on the SD.. and TBH, once I started watching what I was putting onto my +, I realised how much stuff i had on my other phones I never used... Its actually quite refreshing.. 
I have everything on my PC so I swap in and out when I need too and owning a Lumia 1520 in the past.. I have access to a 200GB storage space on OneDrive.
Same as others...128 was not an option. The more, the better. Did the 32 thing with a different phone, never again. Ran into space issues every month.

200gb sandisk here, works great in my Samsung Galaxy S7 Edge. I keep server backups on my cell, just in case I need to fix server issues when I'm not near my computers. Phone seems a little faster since I moved all those files over to the SD card, but it was already lightning fast.

title: Why is my battery life so bad and the cell standby battery use % so high?

thread.text:
I have a Galaxy s6 edge + and recently the battery life has been terrible, not even lasting a day 
According to my battery usage:
Screen = 29% ( it's on auto brightness and generally quite dim)
Cell Standby = 22%
Android OS = 17% (most up to date software) 
Device idle = 10%
Android system = 6%
Spotify = 6% 
I have changed wifi to "keep Wi-Fi on during sleep" to "never" - no change. 
Any suggestions
Thanks in advance

Welcome to Android Central! High Cell Standby battery usage usually means poor cell signal. How is your cell signal throughout the day? Install an app like GSam Battery Monitor to give you a better idea of your cell signal strength.

Hey, 
I live in London, so my signal is pretty strong all the time, the only time is it weak is when I am home, but I am with vodafone and have wifi calling when home over wifi
I read another blog and it recommended 'Keep wifi on during sleep' - I turned that off to 'Never' and that has significantly helped batter life
Since doing that battery usage has changed 
Android OS = 43%
Cell Standby = 30%
Screen = 25%
I have also downloaded Doze - https://play.google.com/store/apps/d....dzzz&hl=en_GB - This may have contributed to my increased battery life 
Any other suggestions welcomed

30% Cell Standby is still pretty high. I wonder if poor cell signal may still impact the battery life, despite using wi-fi calling at home. It would be interesting to compare the battery performance if you spent a day somewhere else, like in a hotel room with good cell signal.

title: Cannot send MMS messages using AT&T MicroCell

thread.text: So we have an AT&T MicroCell because we get a poor signal in our home. It works perfectly for phone and data transmission - except with my shiny new S6 Edge+. For the life of me, I cannot send an MMS picture message when connected to the MicroCell using this phone. It just times out into a "Network Error" message. The iPhones in the house work fine (I'm talking about actual MMS texts, not iMessage), the LG G4 works fine, my father's ancient, crappy little flip phone works fine. But the $900-plus flagship? No dice. The second I unplug the MicroCell, the message goes through with a single bar of AT&T coverage, but come on, what a pain in the arse of a workaround. I love pretty much everything about this phone, but honestly, this is a bit of game-changer if I cannot get it to work properly. I work from home and share a lot of MMS picture texts between friends and colleagues. Any thoughts? Anybody else experience this? Is it a Samsung Galaxy thing? Thanks.

I think the Microcell only uses 3G for mobile data--so if your phone is set for LTE only, it may not be able to use the Microcell for mobile data. On the phone, go to Settings>Connections>Mobile Networks>Network Mode, and make sure it's set to LTE/WCDMA/GSM, and not LTE Only.

Thanks B. Diddy. Unfortunately, I don't have that option available on my phone. My Mobile Networks tab only lists "Mobile Data," "International Data Roaming," "Access Point Names," and "Network Operators." Maybe it's a setting AT&T disables?

An easy way to tell is if your phone's mobile data ever goes down to 3G or HSPA+. Do you ever see that icon in the status bar? I would assume that the default on the phone would be LTE/WCDMA/GSM (i.e., it can access all of those networks), but if you only ever see LTE or nothing, then maybe someone set it up incorrectly at the store or the factory.
I've seen it read 4G many times when connected to the MicroCell. Have never seen 3G, though I seem to recall something awhile back about the way AT&T labeled HSPA+ as 4G. That sound familiar?

Yes, HSPA+ is often labeled 4G (or "pseudo 4G") because it's pretty fast--but still technically 3G. Different phones show this differently. Some phones will show H+ when on HSPA+ and LTE when on LTE. Others might show 4G when on HSPA+, and 4GLTE when on LTE. Unfortunately, I'm not sure what your phone's convention is. The AT&T people might know, but that's not a guarantee.

Well at least I've found an easier workaround. I just switch the Edge+ into and out of airplane mode quickly and the MMS goes through before the Microcell signal takes control. Really strange. I have no problems receiving picture messages, just sending.
Posted via the Android Central App

Having the exact same issue with my Note 3. Can't get a picture out at all See 4G at my house all the time. I also have AT&T MicroCell. A must, because without it I have less than one bar of signal. Airplane mode on/off does reset the data connection. How did I not think of that? Thank you. title: Galaxy s6 edge plus,after the software update, my battery life is awful, what can I do?

Welcome to Android Central! More battery stats would be helpful as well. Charge up to 100%, then let it drain to 20-30% with normal usage, without charging in between. Then show us:
1. The main Settings>Battery screen.
2. The fullscreen battery graph screen (which shows Awake time and Cell Signal Strength).
3. The Screen category (to see total Screen On time).
4. The Cell Standby category, if present (to see Time Without Signal).http://forums.androidcentral.com/amb...d-central.html
Also, here are the steps to wipe the cache: https://support.t-mobile.com/docs/DOC-21095

•	I was frustrated so I went to play some billiards in my game room.
•	He flashed some firmware but it was not the official firmware needed.
•	He restored some unknown firmware using some unknown version of Odin. 
•	I wasn’t watching so I’m not sure what he did.
•	I came to see if he had made any progress and the S6 was in a boot loop.
•	I tried almost every known suggestion on the web and nothing worked.
•	Now the Samsung Galaxy S6 edge plus is stuck in boot loop.
•	I cannot access Android System Recovery Screen by holding Vol. Up + Power + Home. Holding these buttons does nothing no matter how long you hold it.
•	I’m at a total loss now and need some help.
07. Thank you in advance for any information you may have to help me get this S6 straighten out.
--
Regards,
Nolan

title: Why are random pictures imported to my computer?

thread.text: I have a Galaxy S6 Edge+. I've noticed that when I'm importing my photos form my phone to my Dell that random pictures are being imported. I've noticed some of the pictures are ads from a game on my phone. I have no issue deleting that game if there's no way to simply avoid it. I've also noticed that photos I've looked at on Facebook that aren't even mine, peoples FB profile pictures, or just random pictures I look at online end up importing to my photo file on my computer. These pictures aren't even in my gallery on my phone. It's frustrating b/c I already hate this new Dell computer and it's so slow to delete each and every ad picture or picture that's not mine and it's over 500. I've tried researching and can't really find an answer. Any help would be great. TIA

Welcome to Android Central! It sounds like you're using the Import Pictures and Videos feature in Windows Explorer--I suggest not using this feature. It imports all images from the phone indiscriminately, including thumbnails and cached images from apps and the browser. Instead, use Windows Explorer to manually select your photos, then drag and drop them to the computer's hard drive.

thread.text: My phone had fairly good battery life until a couple days ago. Hi, no charging the phone overnight while it's already at 100% won't cause significant damage - I do it every night. 
Since you mentioned the screen is taking the majority of the battery, how is your screen brightness kept on the phone? how much screen on time do you have? 
Can you please register an account with us so you can upload screenshots of the battery usage and we can determine what is draining it for you?

Posted via the Android Central App

Welcome to Android Central! I merged a couple of your threads here.
Charge up to 100%, then let it drain to 20-30% with normal usage, without charging in between. Then show us:
1. The main Settings>Battery screen.
2. The fullscreen battery graph screen (which shows Awake time and Cell Signal Strength).
3. The Screen category (to see total Screen On time).
4. The Cell Standby category, if present (to see Time Without Signal).
The 12% Cell Standby in your screenshot above suggests that there is some time when your cell signal is poor--this can drain your battery. Also, Verizon Cloud is using a decent amount of battery. If you never use it, I suggest clearing its cache and data, then disabling it if possible.
If you can't find a Cell Signal Strength graph in your Battery settings, then install GSam Battery Monitor.
