thread.text:
I had LG G2 (Verizon) and the screen got cracked few days ago so I went ahead and purchased s6 edge+ at full retail price.
It is worth to upgrade if you must have latest technology and unique looking phone specially the platinum gold. The camera is awesome, screen is impressive, fast charging ....etc. Other goodies could be important for some and not so for others. I have seen rare lags in TW specially when you have many home pages and widgets. Chrome lags but I think this is a ad and Chrome issue and not the phone. I have seen many users getting 5-6 hours batter life, I got 5.5 the first charge, but some are getting less than 4 and some more than 6.
If my phone wasn't broken I would have passed the upgrade and waited for the next LG and/or s7 edge+. The edge+ is better phone than LG G2 but I miss the on screen and back buttons. LG G2 got bad after the update to 5.11 as the charging became very slow and the battery does faster and the entire software became a little bit slow. My LG G2 is rooted and I use AdAway to get rid of ads of course TB to freeze bloatware and unneeded apps.
Of course this is my personal opinion but I do not think it is worth to upgrade yet especially if you will pay full retail price. I am taking my phone to fix it and if the cost is reasonable then I will fix it and use it couple of days and may return the Samsung.
Good luck.
I came to the Edge + from the G4, but I went (All Verizon) G2, G3, G4, and now Edge +. By far, the Edge + is the best.http://forums.androidcentral.com/sam...my-review.html

thanks for the info guys, it's been a real help. I was considering iOS but even after looking at their forums, people aren't too happy with the lagginess of iOS 9 apparently. I believe a fix is in the works but the phones need to allow a more individual user experience especially for the price point. Just my opinion though since 13 + million ppl seem to disagree with me on that one.
Anyway, pretty certain that I'll be going the way of the Note 5, I tried both again in the store and the Note just feels more natural to me.

replies.text:
You can't go wrong with a Note 5. I would have gotten that instead of my Edge+ if it was available in 64GB in Canada.
That being said, I love my sexy Edge+.

thread.text:
I've been in between smartphones and OS's every year, but my favorite I'll have to say were Samsung Galaxy 3 and the Note 2. These were pretty solid devices and lighter than most in their time. The last 2 years I'd been with iOS, until I decided to try Android again this week and is great to see how long has Google Android evolved from what it was 3 years ago. I went to my local carrier store and decided to try the cheapest and slowest of them all to measure against what the quality should be and is fair to say that I tried the ZTE Maven running Lollipop 5.1 and it really surprised me how well it did. Of course, the processor can't compare with premium devices, but I decided to use it for a week as my daily driver instead of the iPhone 6 Plus and it surprised me how well it did. It didn't freeze, screen responded quick when navigating around and Notifications never failed to work. I had all this issues with iOS and I'm no gamer, but I do depend on notifications and this little device worked great. I even found it more intuitive to use. I went and jumped ship and glad I did. Battery is an issue, but nothing that can't be solved with a battery pack to keep it charged. 
Android is awesome, 
Thanks Google.

I had this too. It was driving me nuts! Try going into settings, accessibility and see if notification reminder is on. If you click on it, one of the notification settings is vibrate. I have left on the notification reminder because I want it for other things, but you can go through the applications below and turn it off for all of the apps that you want it off on. title: Verizon Unlimited Data is going to cost us more per month beginning in November!

thread.text: Verizon Communications Inc. Hikes Unlimited Data Plan Prices By $20
YupVerizon to raise price of grandfathered unlimited data plan by $20 for those not under contract | Android Central

I performed a check. I've got 2 unlimited lines, so it'll cost me an extra $40 per month. I used 140GB with both phones combined last month. I've seen it as high as 180GB. Verizon's biggest plan is 100GB combined per month and it's well over $700. Even with the additional $40, I'm still going to be around $300, so I'll be staying on my unlimited data.

It doesn't surprise me. They are trying everything they can to take it from you. When I bought the Edge+ I called when I got it to have it activated since I added a line to get it.... because I have unlimited data. They Verizon rep on the phone told me I could not do that.... (I spoke with one when I ordered it, he told me I could do it).. the guy was going to ask his supervisor about me being able to swap lines.... I turned the phone on... that is it... he came back and told me I activated the phone on the line it came on and I canceled my unlimited data. I was pissed.... I told him no I did not because all I did was turn on the phone... that was it. Apparently now when you get a Verizon phone and it has an installed SIM card, all you have to do is turn phone on and it activates. After an hour going around and around with the rep, I got my unlimited data back. And I plan on keeping it... I use alot of data myself...

title: From Note 4 to BB Passport to S6 edge+

thread.text:
My father gifted me a Samsung Galaxy Note 4 6 months ago, when I first used it, it was the best phone I have ever had. Superb 2 day battery life, amazing camera, great screen especially for browsing the web.
Then came the curse called Lollipop update, I thought it's gonna make the phone better.....it only made it laggy, battery life went down from 2 days on average usage to 1 day max.....I hated my Note 4 so much at this point....so then I decided to root the phone and go back to Kit Kat 4.4.4 and by rooting it, I won't be forced to update to Lollipop, that went well initially, battery life became decent again, the lag factor was improved but overall, it's not as I wish, when you open apps like the camera for example, it's not instantaneous....
Additionally, I kept getting random errors saying "TouchWiz has stopped working" so I decided to forget about rooting (Knox warranty is now void though) and went back to Lollipop 5.0.1 but I still got the TouchWiz has stopped working error randomly. Seems like rooting was a bad idea as it seems to have destroyed my phone somehow...
I then sold it and got a BlackBerry Passport because I love physical keyboards..BIG mistake. This akward keyboard that has the numbers and symbols in a virtual keyboard defeats the whole purpose of being able to quickly type what you want, so I found myself actually slower in typing with this hybrid keyboard setup and I misses a lot of my apps even though I was able to sideload them through the Google Play Store they just don't look right because of the scaling.. Then the biggest problem with BlackBerry that I was facing with the BB Q10, BB Classic, and now with the BB Passport......I thought they might have fixed it by now on BB OS 10.3.2 but nope, the problem is randomly I would start getting duplicate contacts everywhere or contacts will just disappear. I lost many contacts in this process that I was now sick of BlackBerry and swore never to buy a BlackBerry again.....
So again, I was shopping for a new phone. I want a phone with a good camera as I don't have a digital camera and I want it to be super snappy and fast. Since I would never touch any iToy because I hate how hard it is to transfer songs to my phone using iTunes, my next choice was the Galaxy Note 5 even though that doesn't seem like a real upgrade from the Note 4 but it's still the best.....
Unfortunately, they don't sell the Note 5 in 64GB here in Dubai only 32GB and with no expandable SD Card slot, that won't do it for me since my data by itself (MP3s, Videos, Pics) is around 30GB by itself.
They do however sell the Galaxy S6 edge+ in 64GB so I asked the sales rep what is the difference between this and the Note 5 and she said the only difference is that it has no S-Pen! GREAT! I never used that gimmick even once on my Note 4 and didn't want an extra burden to worry about breaking it or losing it.
So I bought the Galaxy S6 edge+ Gold Color 64 GB and here is my mini review:
Build Quality = This is the highest quality phone I ever owned! Feels very premium and luxurious because of its platinum gold color.
Battery life = 2 days easily with moderate usage, I think the battery life is a bit better than the Note 5 due to the lack of the S-Pen but maybe I'm just imagining things. I was surprised that even though the batter is smaller in capacity than the Note 4 which has a 3200mAH battery and this one has a 3000mAH battery, the battery life is actually better. Mind you I never turn off any features, I want to enjoy everything in my phone so location is on, WiFi is on, 4G is on, you name it.
OS = It comes pre-loaded with Lollipop 5.1 so I didn't get all the bugs/glitches that were in 5.0.1, that's great.
PS: when I sold my Note 4 just a week back, it still hadn't received the update to 5.1 I think Samsung are practicing a cheap trick by not offering the update to the older phones to force people to buy their next new phone.
Snappiness = I am very sensitive to lag, this phone gives me the 0 lag factor even after owning it for 4 days and installing all my apps and literally torturing it. Love how everything opens instantly.
Example, on the Note 4, when I hit the active apps virtual button to get a scroll list of all my running apps, scrolling through them is super laggy and slow as if I was using a phone from the year 2000 with outdated hardware. With the Note 6 Edge+, scrolling through all my apps is super smooth. It's a night and day difference.
Camera = First of all, Samsung replaced the stupid shortcut of launching S-Voice by double tapping the home key which was one of the most useless apps ever IMHO and now replaced that shortcut to make it launch the camera when you double tap the home key. As simple as this sounds, this is a superb feature! now when you see something and want to quickly grab your phone to take a photo, all it takes is to double tap the home key button twice and the camera launches in less than a second!
I took a few photos of my cats with the camera and I was blown away by how fast the auto focus works and how sharp and vibrant the pictures look I could almost swear this was taken by a DSLR camera!
I am simply blown away by this phone. I am a very picky person usually but this phone fits all my needs and does it with style.
Picture example of a photo taken by the S6 edge+:

Great review. I agree with most of it  I do think the Edge + is the best SmartPhone I've had since 4G came out, but I do like iToys as well  However, I'm not even tempted to look at the 6s because I love my Edge+

F the phone! I want your kittehs! 
I like the review though. I'm camping on my 4.4.4 Note Edge for now because I can't live without my snappy Edge screen.

thread.text: That usually means that your cell signal has been generally poor. Does the Settings>Battery menu show you what your cell signal has been like, if you tap the battery graph and make it fullscreen? If not, install GSam Battery Monitor and see what it reports over the span of one full charge.
Known bug with Lollipop. Haven't been able to find anyone who has a fix without hacking the phone.

As others have said, a poor signal will give you poor battery life. However, most of the time this issue is from your phone constantly checking for location. Change your location settings to Power Saving.

thread.text:
Update, since doing the following, I haven't experienced this freezing bug when unlocking:
1- Power off your phone
2- Hold the Volume Up + Home + Power Button simultaneously to start your device in the advanced mode
3- Wipe Cache partition twice
4- Reboot your phone
5- Install Package Disable Pro and only disable the Ant+ Radio crap + BBC Agent + Briefing + com.android.providers.partnerbookmarks + DCMProvider + Hangouts + Market Feedback Agent + Safety Information + SapaMonitor
6- Install SD Maid Pro and let it clean everything it finds
7- Run Smart Manager which should be preinstalled on your phone, and select Clean ALL
8- Reboot your phone

Have you tried flashing with the latest firmware from Samsung mobile? 
Sent from my SM-G928F using Tapatalk

title: Question about music player

thread.text: I added christmas list of songs for when it comes to that time and they are in my main list however i added them in their own seperate folder. Is there a way to not see those ones when im listening to all my other music?

The system scans all folders for music files to add to the Music app's database. It doesn't read them as separate folders. You could hide those files from the Music app by using a file manager app to add a blank text file titled ".nomedia" (no quotes) in that directory. Once you're ready for the music files to appear in the Music app, delete that .nomedia file.

You can leave Facebook on, but disable Continuous Contact Upload in the app settings. Basically turning off Facebook's background process. I found that that made a big difference. 
This is a good reminder, though, to double check what's been disabled. I get why it disables Facebook because it can have such an effect on battery life, but for me it also disabled IMDb and the Kindle app, both of which use pretty much no battery even in the foreground. 
Still highly recommended though. :-)

title: Issue with smart security lock

thread.text:
I have it set to not lock when I'm at home. My location is always on yet whenever I leave my house and come back.. I have to keep unlocking my phone with my fingerprint, where as I have it set up to not lock when I'm at home. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't. I'm home right now and it's not working. Anyone else have this issue?
Posted via the Android Central App

Is your Location set to High Accuracy (i.e., using the GPS radio), or Battery Saving (using only the wi-fi and cell signals)? Battery Saving isn't as accurate, and can sometimes be a few hundred yards off. This might be far enough out of the Trusted Location radius that the phone won't unlock automatically.

It is on high, yes.
Posted via the Android Central App

Are you using a Network Extender? My NE lost it's gps signal and I had the same problem.

Hi.
I asked myself the same thing. First option is out of discussion. Now between Edge plus and S6+ I don't thing you should have too much doubts. Edge is far away better. TW seems very responsive. I didn't encountered issues regarding it. Also jn my wife's Galaxy S6 it's working properly. All lags issues are related to third part applications that are not optimized so take your time and test them properly. I now own a galaxy edge 6 plus, coming from a Galaxy Note 4 and I can tell you that Edge Plus is for the moment the best in class smartphone. 
Trimis de pe al meu SM-G928F folosind Tapatalk

You should make this a Poll Question. Just go in and edit it in the Advanced settings and I think you can add a Poll.
My vote would be for the Edge +. Keep in mind, I had the iPhone 6 Plus last year, which is almost identical to the 6S Plus this year. I can compare the two models here. I have not owned a Nexus, so I can't comment on it.Lag: I loved the smoothness of the iPhone and how there was no lag, but there is no lag with the Edge + either.Signal: Both phones have a comparable signal and both perform well as a phone. I know, right?Call Volume: Sammy gets the "edge" here. I had problems hearing the caller on my iPhone. However, to be honest, I think it was more the placement of the ear speaker, then the actual speaker volume. Sometimes I'd move the ipHone around and be able to get a louder volume. The Edge + is great as far as caller volume. No issues.Screen: Both perform well, but I do love the aspect ratio of the iPhone screens over Android Screens. The iPhone has a more cinematic size and the Androids have a more Widescreen TV size, IMO.Camera: Once again, comes down to the size for me. Edge + has a wider field of view than the iPhone 6 Plus, so Sammy here. Both take outstanding photos.Response Time: Both phones open apps fast, and both run the apps smoothly as I said above. The Sammy's camera is super quick to open up and the iPhone's camera is noticeably slower to open. Both have quick shutters and can take multiple pictures at one time. Maybe a slight edge to the Sammy because the camera app opens faster than any phone I've ever seen. Double click the home button and the camera's open and ready.Battery Life: Nothing beats an iPhone for battery life. It's at least 2 to 1 as far as comparing the two and in some cases I could actually push that to 3 to 1 for my useage of the two phones. iPhone 6 Plus I charged every night during the week and never charged it during the weekend. NEVER! Edge + I charge 2 to 3 times per day and nightly if I'm not using the Hotspot on weekends.Charging: Edge + of course. Qi + fast charging, hands down. Why Apple hasn't come out with either or both of these is beyond me.Hotspot: The reason I purchased the Edge + and sold my iPhone 6 Plus. The ANdroid Hotspot works everywhere with every device, including Apple. The Apple hotspot only works well with other Apple devices. It isn't worth a dang for a non-iOS device. My phones are my Internet at home, so the hotspot must function well.
My 2 pennies. Take 'em for what they are worth.

Get the Nexus 6P. Pure Android Experience + latest updates FTW.
Samsung sucks when it comes to updating their OS and it's very laggy due to TouchWiz

replies.text:
I don't agree with that statement for this phone. ^^^
I do agree with that statement for previous models, but not the Edge +

My mother's Note 4 was no lag last year.
My wife's S6 edge was no lag 4 months ago
I believe edge plus is no lag now. I am not sure a few months later

you have a point there, it's not on the edge+ for the first week, then it's there but to a minimal due to the edge+'s super specs. But in general, if I were to buy a new phone right now, I'd love the vanilla Android with now Samsung bloat

thread.text:
Actually I have better battery experience on Samsung than Apple.
I think it depends on use habit. 
Watching movie and playing game, my mother's note 4 lasts way longer than my iphone 6 plus. I lose 36% battery on iphone 6 plus for palying 45 mins 2048. I do not think it is acceptable. 
Iphone won on listening music and standby time. I think Samsung has longer SOT since OLED.

Right now I'm using the Edge+ and my partner has the iPhone 6 plus. The 6S plus is not that much different, although heavier. Get the Edge+.
It is by far the best looking of the bunch, especially in Silver or Gold. This isn't even opinion it's just fact.
It's also a LOT lighter than the 6s plus. Like coming from the Note 4 (176g) to this (154g) it's very noticeable. There's a lot less wrist fatigue when using it one-handed, I can't imagine how bad the 6s plus would be at almost 200g.
Wireless charging and fast charging. Enough said. I don't even use fast-charging, I bought myself a couple of Tylt Vu wireless chargers. Look it up, unlike other wireless charging "pads", with this one it's a tilted phone stand, no hunting for the sweet spot. I just drop my Edge+ and it's charging, and with the tilted view I can see when my notifications pop up.
I know TouchWiz lag is all too well-known, but I personally have never experienced it. I've had the S3, Note 3, Note 4, and this guy but all I do is install Nova Launcher as soon as I get them and I go year to year without any UI lag. Not to mention that with the included Smart Manager out of the box, you can basically run the S6 edge+ like an iPhone. Choose and set which apps are allowed to run in the background and you can run a tight ship with your background processes just like iOS does.
Last but not least, better camera. Not to say that the 6s camera is bad, iPhones NEVER have bad cameras and for the longest time it was the king of easy-to-use yet great photos for phone cameras, but not anymore. The competition has caught up on shutter speed (the iPhone's main advantage) and are now just as fast when snapping photos but in some cases, produce superior results. This is exactly what the Edge+ has, a super speedy snapper with more dynamic range, better auto-HDR mode, more stable OIS in video recording, not to mention a lot more zoomability because of more megapixels.
The only areas the iPhone beats the Edge+ is standby battery, slow-motion video recording, OS updates and I guess the app store. 
The Edge+ slimmer, lighter, and has an overall smaller footprint while having a bigger (not to mention higher resolution) screen. Android has more customizability, compatibility (wireless charging, Samsung pay) and versatility (Wi-fi hotspots, true NFC) than iOS. Unless you're heavily invested in Apple's ecosystem you will find it very hard to find good reasons to pick the 6s plus over the Edge+.
I'll leave you with a youtube video comparing the Edge+, 6s plus and G4 cameras. Notice how Samsung wins 3 out of 5 categories and yet (shamefully) the testers still declare there's no clear winner in the contest. But unless you're blind, the winner is obvious. 
A much more unbiased and comprehensive comparison of the phones as a whole from Pocketnow here: 
Good luck, in the end only you can decide which phone is right for you. Go with whatever feels right.

thread.text:
@OP, it sounds like you didn't read up on the device before you purchased and simply got the phone and assumed it was a successor to the Note Edge. Next time don't assume, always do research before a big purchase so you don't end up disappointed. This phone was never marketed as a successor to the Note Edge. It was advertised as a PLUS model of the regular S6 edge, which is nothing like the Note Edge.
Maybe you can take it back and stick to your Note Edge if you haven't sold it yet. Sorry to say but I don't think a successor to the Note Edge is in the horizon. That model was wildly unpopular, a stark contrast to the current crop of edge models which are selling like hotcakes. Sure, the new edge models have far less edge features than the old Note Edge but they are light years ahead in terms of premium industrial design, and that's their selling point. There are those who were captivated by the old edge functions, in which case it's best to stick with what you have, especially if you can't live without the older, more functional edge screen.

title: Torn between S6 Edge+ and S7

thread.text:
I know it's too early to tell exactly what Samsung has in store for us when their next release cycle comes around, but I was wondering if there are others here who are holding off on getting the S6 Edge+ until they get more leaks on what the S7 could be like?
The S6E+ is a great device, but I just don't find it to be too much of an upgrade to the S6E, which is already half a year old by now, to win me over. Since the next S phone is coming out in about 5 months or so, I'm debating between keeping my Note 4 for a while longer or upgrading to the S6E+ now. Nothing's been 100% confirmed yet but there have already been leaks on the S7 regarding specs (came up in AnTuTu and GeekBench listings with a Snapdragon 820 and Exynos 8890 variants), design changes (Magnesium alloy unibody, Turtle glass, dual camera). 
Anyone else on the fence about getting either device? Or for those already with the S6E+, would you recommend getting it now or just wait for more reliable info on the upcoming device? Are you planning on upgrading your Edge when it comes out?

Firstly, please read this thread: http://forums.androidcentral.com/sam...edge-plus.html
Secondly: The Note 4 is a pile of garbage after updating to Lollipop, horrible battery life and super laggy
Thirdly, The Note 6 edge+ firstly has a bigger screen than the S7 will. It has the best camera on the market for a smart phone, it has the 0 lag effect, even after using it for 5 days and installing all my apps, it is still super snappy. Everything launches in a split second. Doube tapping the home screen button launches the camera in a sec so you never miss that magical moment you want to shoot. I don't know what more do you want from a smart phone. But if you want to play the waiting game, there will always be something better coming round the next corner. I say, buy the best of the best now, worry about tomorrow later.
just my 2 cents worth. don't be waiting forever and start enjoying the latest technology.

replies.text:
ohh great! what a relief.....
sorry for being such a n00b but what's PET and what's the difference between PET and Tempered glass?
I was always under the impression that tempered glass is best because when I had an iToy 6, people used to tell me if you have a normal screen protector and it drops, the glass would be shattered, hence why everyone recommended tempered glass

thread.text:
Tempered glass IS better, because it's glass. So the feel is better, the protection is better, the look is better. PET is a polymer based film (i.e. a type of plastic) that will prevent most scratches but offers little to no impact protection. It also causes a slight drag when running your finger across the screen as it is not as smooth as glass, but it's not a big deal. The reason tempered glass isn't going to be good for the Edge series is due to the curved edges of the screen. Most manufacturers won't spend the engineering R&D to make the perfect screen protector since there will be a new phone in 6 months to a year anyway. The money just isn't there
Sent from my SM-G928T using Tapatalk

title: Skinomi Tech Glass Review

thread.text:
Okay guys and gals, I had a big long review typed out with a TLDR section and all, but the AC app decided to crash when I went to upload pics. I guess that's the price of being a beta tester...
The review covered the Skinomi Tech Glass Screen Protector. It is a tempered glass screen protector and seems to do a pretty good job. 
Anyway, since that review is now history, I'll post the TLDR version. 
Pros:
- Price($24.95 + $2.95 S&H when I bought it) 
- Tempered Glass 
- Lifetime Replacement (never tried, but it's listed on the package) 
- No loss of responsiveness. Still 100% accurate as far as I can tell. 
- It covers the entire screen. 
Cons:
- There's a definite hit in terms of screen clarity. It's not terrible, but it's noticeable; especially on whites and greys. 
- The protector covers the front facing camera. It's a clear piece, but still. 
- The sprinkles in the black on the top and bottom of the protector. 
Mileage May Vary:
- When I installed it, I used the standard side-to-side version of the hinge method. It's much harder to get lined up on this phone. I might suggest a modified version of the hinge going from top to bottom. 
Overall Score: 3.7/5
Link to purchase:https://www.amazon.com/dp/B014K3471U...cUvbUpU4711001
Posted via the Android Central App
Pictures of the package and materials. If I had another camera I'd have shown a picture of it installed.

thread.text:
If you are unable to use Voice & Data on a call this could be a CDMA limitation.[INFO]The older phones had two CDMA radios put in them (such as the S3 on Sprint). One dedicated to voice -- another dedicated to data. Therefore you could do voice and data. GSM has always been one radio because that one radio can do both tasks at the same time. They got around it on CDMA by simply adding another radio in there and dedicating each one to one task.
Now they're getting rid of that second CDMA radio. So therefore you can only use talk, or data -- not both at the same time. Now if you're using VoLTE for your calls it will allow voice and data since the call will be going through LTE (as data) so it is technically then all data which would bypass this restriction.[/INFO]

Hey guys,
I also just started having this problem and have been searching for solutions. I've read claims that range from blaming it on your carrier, your phone, and 3G vs. 4G. Since this issue only just started happening I knew they were baseless. So I dug into my settings and figured it out.
If you open the settings on the phone app itself, I have the choice of "General" or "Calls." Select "Calls." There will be a place to choose "Voice Privacy - Enable enhanced privacy mode." Un-select this. 
Your problems should be over.

title: Switched from the G4 to Edge + (My Review)

thread.text:
(Updated 9/22 after several weeks with the phone)
OK, so I’ve been around the block with phones, but so far I’ve stayed away from Samsung for the past 3 years. It started with the Samsung Charge. I hated that phone. It was buggy, laggy, short battery life, and overall one of the worse phones I’ve ever owned. Not the worse mind you. (I did own a BlackBerry Storm.) Then I tried a Samsung Galaxy 3. I thought it was ok, but it was huge for the time. I ended up dropping it within 2 days of owning it and completely destroying the glass. I still have it by the way and it does act as a fill in phone when I need one. So, after that I started down the Motorola path. Loved the Droid Razr line. Great phones, but eventually they’d become laggy. Then they just stopped making new Razrs and moved on to the Turbo, so I moved on to the LG line. Loved that line until the Verizon version of the G4. After seeing the Edge + and watching several reviews regarding it, I decided to order one. I’m glad I did. I don’t know if it’ll rank up there with the iPhone 6+ or HTC Droid Incredible (Dinc) as one of my favorite phones, but so far it’s pushing its way to the top.
Finger Print Sensor – Sammy finally made one that works almost as good as Apple’s. It’s close enough for me. I’ve only had to try again 3 times since setting it up. (After reentering the same thumb 2 times and the other hand's thumb, I haven't had it not recognize my thumb. It's a great sensor.)
Screen – I mean what can you say? It’s gorgeous. The most beautiful screen I’ve seen in a long time. It is bright enough to see outdoors.  If I had a complaint it would be that it doesn’t get very dark in a dark room, but there are screen filters that can be added for that. Watching NetFlix on it is perfect. Gaming is sweet. No complaints. It is very interesting to note however, that the extra .2” screen size is not noticeable. In fact, I had to put it up against the G4 to see any difference in the two screen sizes. 
Build Quality – Something to behold. For years I’ve been saying that Apple makes the highest build quality devices. Well, Sammy’s giving Apple a run for its money now. The aluminum finish is great. It feels solid and has some heft when holding it which is a good thing. Plastic phones always seem difficult to hold on to because they are too light. If I was going to complain, it would be the back. You cannot keep the back clean. As soon as you even think about touching it, it gets a fingerprint on it. I do have the Sammy slim case on order and hopefully it’ll arrive today. This should help with holding on to it and keep the back from looking like a 3 year old’s been playing with it. (I received the Sammy slim case and wasn't happy about the protection quality, so I did end up purchasing the Incipio case. I'm not wild about the Incipio just because it's hard pushing the buttons, so I might end up going back to the Sammy case. Either way, if you don't use a case, you will have fingerprints.)
Camera – Coming from the G4, I didn’t expect the camera quality to be even par with LG’s, but I have to say it takes great photos. At least for the few I’ve taken. Wifey’s got the Sammy G5 and it’s a piece of crap as far as cameras go, but so far the shots I’ve taken with the Edge + look nice. (Great camera. At least as good as the G4, maybe even slightly better with the lighting quality.)
Sammy UI – They’ve cleaned up the UI a lot since my last Sammy product. I have to say it is less intrusive. While it’s not the stock Android, it seems to run smoothly and respond as fast as you would expect. I’ve never been a fan of TouchWiz, because it got in the way of my Android experience, but so far I am not finding that to be the case with this version. (No issues with the UI. Really haven't found any issues using the phone or with any of the Sammy software.)
Edge Display – This is something to keep in mind if you’re trying to decide between the Note 5 or the Edge +. Personally I’ve never been a fan of the Note line and doubt I’d ever use the S Pen, so for me it was all about the look and feel of the phone. I really dig the look of the Edge + over the Note 5. However, the edge display seems like a gimmick to me. I’ve setup a few things, but really, I’m not using it hardly at all. Maybe I will in the future, but so far it’s eh. I will say I like the fact that movies “fall off the cliff” so to speak and look good watching them using it. However, not the same experience with gaming. Since the game also flows into the edges were you normally hold it, I have accidently pressed the screen when I didn’t want to. I do wish the games didn’t use the entire screen. Maybe some updates from the gaming developers will fix this. Or at least they need to turn off the touching ability on the edge during their game app. It’s a developer problem though, not a Samsung problem. (Maybe gimmick wasn't the right word. I do like the infinity display look and it's great for watching Netflix and playing games.)
Battery Life – It seems to be a little better than my G4, which is good as they both use a 3000 mAh battery. I’m really hard on phone batteries, but I have been able to squeeze another hour of the phone. Before you say that’s why you need a replaceable battery, batteries do not go bad now days as they did in the past. I have no doubt this phone will be long gone and a memory by the time the battery gives up the ghost. More on the battery in a minute. As for battery life, it's the normal Android Subpar. If you're coming from an iPhone be prepared to hate the life of any Android battery. Yes people. I know there are steps that you can take to extend the life of the battery, but those who come from iPhones know that the steps should have to be taken. It's not horrible, but it's nowhere close to the life of an iPhone. This is an Android issue, not a Sammy issue is all I'm saying.)
Problems: 
Why no SD Card slot? They could have integrated it with the dual SIM of the European models. I do see me running out of space quick with this 32GB version. I’m already thinking that I have to clear out the old photos quickly and can only put 1 or 2 shows on it at a time, so an external SD Card would have been highly desirable on my list of needs. Can I live without it? I’m going to find out. (32GB has been fine for me so far. No need for an external SD Card, but it would have been nice to have one.)
Lack of removable battery. This one doesn’t bother me as much. Let’s face it, with today’s external battery backups, there’s no reason to run out of power in your phone. In fact, I’ve only had a few phones with replaceable batteries since switching from my beloved Dinc, so I don’t see this as a problem. I’m sure some will, though.
I’m not going to say that this is the phone I’m finally keeping for years to come. Let’s face it, I’m not that guy. I can say that this is a great phone and one that I’m very happy I purchased. Who knows, maybe I’ll keep it for a year? I do really like it and I do rank it up there with my beloved Dinc and iPhone 6+. Final Update: So now I'm ranking it as the best 4G phone I've had, including the iPhone. It runs smooth as silk still and looks beautiful doing it. Yes, I want a longer battery life out of my phone, but let's face it, Android battery life is what it is. The quick charge is great and gets it back up to 80% really quick, so I don't need a replaceable battery. I haven't had to pull out my external battery charger yet, so that's a plus. I told my wife the other day, that this is the last 4G LTE phone I'll buy for myself. If Verizon lets me keep my unlimited data and move up to a 5G phone in the next few years when 5G comes out, then I'll entertain buying a 5G phone to replace this one. Otherwise I do not plan on buying another phone. I did purchase a 3 year SquareTrade warranty last week making it official. No more phones. I'm done buying. This is it.

You can make the fingerprint sensor more accurate by adding multiple fingerprint profiles with the same finger or thumb. I have 2 profiles set up with each thumb and it works every time. 
As far as the edge screen. I don't think it's gimmicky at all. I use it more than I ever used my s pen. Once you get used to using it for your top 5 people and top 5 apps it's hard to think of ever having to go back to doing it the old way of searching for the app or searching through your contacts. 
The only problem I've found with the phone is sometimes when I plug in the charger that came with the box it is not always detecting it as a fast charger and is charging at regular speeds and the Samsung wireless charger that worked flawlessly with my regular s6e does not work properly with my s6e plus.
Posted via the Android Central App

title: S6 Edge Plus Default Apps Keep Resetting

thread.text: Just got a new Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge Plus and every time I install ANY new app, I lose all my default application settings. So every time I try to run something, it'll ask me what application I'd like to use. So annoying to have to set them all up again every time I install any app. Anyone else have this problem?
Hello, welcome to the forums! It's normal that installing a new app will reset some defaults, but only those actions that can be performed by this new app.

Unfortunately, this is every default setting. Example, today I installed a world clock widget. Shortly thereafter, every default application was wiped out. Literally. I went to the default apps menu in the settings page, and it was blank. This happens with any app that I install.
That doesn't sound normal at all. Let me check with some experts.

Any updates to the OS recently? You might want to try a cache clear in recovery, or the settings menu.
From my G4
Android Central Ambassador Team Leader

Try to go to the application manager and clear app data and cache on the settings app 
Sent from my Verizon Samsung Galaxy Note 5

So, I tried everything listed. Everything was fine until I installed a new app. Then all default apps settings got reset again. I should probably add that it's not immediately after installing an app. It's usually about a few hours after. Can't say for sure it's the installation of a new app that's causing it. But I will say that I haven't had the problem for more than a week until today. I didn't install any new apps during the last week until today. Then bam, after instalkinf a new app, all my default apps were wiped out today.

Disregard the last message. Finally figured out what it was. Turns out its due to the Samsung Kids Mode app. Just so happened that most apps I recently installed were for my daughter, and I would launch Kids Mode shortly thereafter. Took me a while, but finally figured it out. Thanks to all on this list for your help though!

title: Andrew, please help with the Youtube Live Streaming

thread.text:
I just got my Edge+ on Monday and I'm trying to get the Youtube Live Streaming to work. Here's what I do:
1) Open camera app with double press of Home button
2) Select MODE and select Live Broadcast
3) Camera app switches to Live Broadcast interface and shows the Disclaimer and asks me to AGREE. I click AGREE.
4) Camera app shows a pop up and asks me to sign in to Youtube. I click Sign In and put in my Google e-mail and password.
5) 2-Factor authentication gives me a code and I put it in. Seems to work okay.
6) Mini Youtube browser pops up and says "You are already enabled for this feature". Message disappears but mini browser stays open on top of camera app.
7) To close the mini browser, I have to hit the Back button. After hitting Back button, pop up reappears and asks me to sign into Youtube again.
8) This process is an endless loop and I cannot get the Live broadcast to work. It keeps asking me to sign in and then tells me I an enabled, but then pops back up again.
Tried force closing camera app, clearing camera app data, rebooting phone, signing out of Youtube and back in again. Not sure what else to try? I'm thinking either 1) there is an authentication problem between the Samsung camera app and my Youtube account, or 2) Live Broadcast just isn't working yet?
Andrew, have you gotten it to work yet or given it a try?
Thanks!

replies.text: This is not a Samsung issue, I experienced the same trying to set the Sony Xperia Z3 feature that basically does the same, back in Sept/Oct. last year. I can't remember exactly the steps I did to fix it, but was nothing on the phone, so save some time and don't keep changing settings on the phone, that's not it. What I remember the most was something related to the way Google/YouTube handles the login and I think some permissions, so explore that and please post back your results so others can have the solution once you find it.

thread.text:
Thanks. I thought maybe it was 2 factor authentication that was causing the problem, so I created an app specific password. Tried that but then it told me I need to use my regular Google password. 
Looked all over in the YouTube settings but everything looks good. Live streaming is enabled and working in a browser on my pc. If you think of what you did to fix it, please post it. If I figure it out, I will post back here as well.
Sent from my SAMSUNG-SM-G928A using Tapatalk

I got it working! I searched for similar issue with Xperia and found out it was because I have more than one YouTube account on my Google profile (because of google+). Once I enabled YouTube live streaming on my Google+ YouTube account, it worked flawlessly. Only problem is that I don't want to stream to that amount... I want to user my actual YouTube account. Still trying to figure out how to switch accounts from the camera app.
Sent from my SAMSUNG-SM-G928A using Tapatalk

Yes, I also have 2 YouTube accounts linked to my Google account and yes, I remember that it was related to something like that but really can't remember what I did exactly, I'll try to see if I posted my findings on this or other forums, if I find something I'll let you know here.

I spend quite a bit of time today trying to figure out a solution to this problem. The good news is that I got Live Broadcast to work from my phone. The bad news is that it's using the wrong Youtube channel. I have a Google account that has a default Google+ youtube channel, and then I have my main Youtube channel that has a username instead of my real name. That channel has all of my videos, subscriptions, and the like, so that's where I want my live broadcasting to go to.
Unfortunately, the camera app on the S6 Edge+ doesn't seem to want to use that channel no matter what I do. I can get the little mini browser to sign out of my default channel and login with the right Youtube channel. But then I just get a message saying "This feature is already enabled" and then it just loops again trying to sign in. Only when I switch back to the other Youtube channel will it live broadcast.
I tried to work around this by migrating my Google+ youtube channel around, but I ended up getting timed out by Google, and now it won't let me delete or change the channel. Apparently there is a week delay before I can make changes again. I think what I need to do is "move" the Youtube channel I want to use to my main Google+ account profile, thereby deleting the Youtube channel I don't use that was created by default with my Google+ page. I don't know, this is all so confusing with Google integrating Google+, Youtube, pages, profiles, channels, etc. This whole mess started when they forced everyone to use Google+.
So while I wait a week to move my channel, I'm just going to play around with the Live broadcasting on the wrong channel.... at least I can have a little fun with it privately.
Thanks for the help!

How to fix the Galaxy Note 5 and S6 Edge+ YouTube live streaming ‘already enabled’ error | 9to5Google That's the link that helped me broadcast to sub channels instead of the main home channel I don't use the live broadcasting on

title: S6 edge Plus slowing down?

thread.text:
I brought my phone from Best buy, with the carrier of AT&T I was very happy with it. It was extremely increasingly fast. But at the second day it was a little bit of delay, It was slowing down, Laggy scrolling, So I watch some videos to make it go faster. In a video it showed that removing caches and downloading the vitamin samsung mobile app (Suppose to clean up the RAM) I did it but noting improved, So I need to make it go like it supposed to be. Switch from a iphone. Trying out a andriod for the first time. Also I'm new here. Thanks and please give me tips to make it faster like it suppose to be.
Posted via the Android Central App

Welcome to Android Central! Don't bother with "RAM cleaners." The way they work is contrary to how the Android system wants to work, so any benefit you see is very brief, and overall it may actually be counterproductive.
Do you typically power the phone down when you're not using it? If so, then don't do that--just put the screen to sleep. I seem to recall seeing some posts about how the phone seems to be laggier after a cold boot--perhaps because it has to rebuild a lot cached data.
You can also boot into Safe Mode to see if the issue is due to a 3rd party app that you installed: https://support.t-mobile.com/docs/DOC-21007

replies.text:
I take back my original remark. I went ahead and pulled the trigger on the IQ Shield from Amazon and installed it last night (just the front one, not the full body). This is the one you apply with the wet spray, and I was a bit skeptical. But for less than $10, I figured it was worth a shot. Surprisingly, it works rather well! It was a cinch to apply using the wet spray and it left no bubbles or blemishes that I can see. Furthermore, the protector even covers the edges, though I had to hold it down for about 10 seconds to get it to adhere. As for the protector itself, it feels great and is almost imperceptible on my phone. It shows a little more fingerprints than the actual screen, but it doesn't feel resistive like some of those other ones like the Zagg Invisible Shield. There is a slight texture to it if you look in bright light, but it doesn't reduce the clarity of the screen. It also shouldn't get in the way of a case if you're using one (I'm using a thin Spigen case that is basically just a clear back and bumper).
Anyway, I'd highly recommend this for those that want a protector:http://www.amazon.com/Shield-LiQuidS...cUvbUpU4641906

replies.text:
Regularly discharging a lithium battery to 15% is going to kill it pretty quickly. The ideal charge point for long life is 50%. 40% isn't too bad. 15% is bad.
(That goes for the power pack too - don't discharge it lower than 40% if its capacity.)
That's the one I have. Works very well.

title: Just used Samsung Pay!

thread.text:
Just used Samsung Pay today. It's pretty awesome! Did anyone else get in the beta?
Posted via the Android Central App

replies.text:
I was literally going to post the exact same thing! I got my beta invite e-mail earlier today and scanned in my CC right away. That process was simple. Then I went down to Best Buy and bought a Bluray. I was a little apprehensive both for myself and the cashier: for myself so I wouldn't look stupid if it didn't work and for the cashier who probably had no idea what I was doing.
In hindsight, it went very well! I told the cashier what I was doing before I did it, and she seemed eager for me to try it. I swiped up from my screen, used my fingerprint to authenticate, and then held the phone to the barcode scanner. It worked flawlessly, and she seemed quite intrigued as well. It's a compliment to say that it worked every bit as good as Apple Pay when I was using that on my iPhone. Of course, Samsung Pay works with barcode scanners which is a big plus (even though NFC is coming to Best Buy later this year).
The only thing I missed was being able to have my Best Buy Rewards card on my phone so I could use the phone to scan that as well. As it stands, if I want my points, I still have to get that card out and have it scanned before paying. I know Apple has been implementing store cards and rewards cards into their payment system, so hopefully Samsung can do the same.

To help save yourself with carrying the card around, download Cardstar from the Play Store. I've been using it quite a while now and haven't carried a physical card around in years.
Posted via the Android Central App

Very cool, hoping I get an invite soon. 
How exactly does it work using a magnetic card terminal, aka not an NFC terminal? What is the process?

replies.text:
It's really no different from the user perspective. Instead of holding the phone up to the NFC contact, you simply hold the phone up to the barcode reader where you would normally scan you card. You don't even have to touch it - just get very close. Technologically, it still uses a token so your credit card number is not actually shared with the merchant, and it is authenticated using your fingerprint or password.
The biggest hurdle (at least here in the USA) is that many places take your actual credit card for payment, such as many sit-down restaurants. Even Samsung Pay isn't going to work here, though some restaurants (like Olive Garden for example) are putting cashier terminals right at your table for you to pay yourself. With these, Samsung Pay would presumably work even if the actual terminal doesn't have NFC. As long as it lets you swipe your card, you should be able to use it. At gas stations, I have read that you have to at least insert some kind of card into the reader for it to activate, then you can hold your phone up to it - but YMMV.

So I've been in the beta for over a week now, but I've only had a few chances to use Samsung Pay. Where I've used it, it's worked great. But to be honest, being able to use it at magnetic stripe readers isn't really that more beneficial than when I had Apple Pay on my iPhone. Why is that? Because almost everywhere I go, they take my physical credit card to make the payment rather than having a terminal for me to use myself. I'm certainly NOT going to hand them my phone so they can make the payment for me using Samsung Pay.
So until more merchants at least have terminals that you can use to pay yourself, NONE of these mobile payment systems are going to allow you to leave your wallet at home. That's just a big lie and they know it. I'd say about 90% of the restaurants I go to require you to give them your credit card while they walk away and charge your card. However, I was pleasantly surprised to find that Olive Garden now has terminals right at your table to pay with, and Samsung Pay worked great there!
I am not disappointed in Samsung Pay, but I am disappointed that we are behind the times in the USA with regards to mobile payments and upgrading terminals. I think it's going to take many years for this to take off here, unfortunately. Yes, I'll continue to use it whenever I get the chance, but there's NO chance I'll be leaving my wallet (or any of my cards) at home.

replies.text: I guess I'm not understanding the advantage. Are you able to use it with a credit card machine that doesn't have NFC?
Yes as long as the machine has a magnetic strip where you can slide a card you should be able to use samsung pay. That is what separates it from other mobile payment systems that only use nfc.

Yes, and that's a huge advantage. Despite more and more merchants adding NFC terminals, the vast majority still only have magnetic stripe readers. With a payment service like Apple Pay, the terminal MUST support NFC, so you are pretty limited to a small subset of merchants. Samsung Pay works with NFC just like Apple Pay, but it ALSO works with nearly every standard magnetic stripe reader. And you don't have to do anything different - you just hold the phone close to the magnetic stripe reader and it works! And of course, it's secured by Samsung Knox and uses the same tokenized method that means your actual credit card information is not sent to the merchant.
As I outlined before, the biggest hurdle (even for Samsung Pay) is the merchants that don't have a POS terminal for the customer to actually use for payment. So places that take your credit card and pay for you (which unfortunately means most sit-down restaurants), you're still out of luck. The antiquated method of handing a cashier your credit card must die!

title: Got locked out of my edge+

thread.text:
Wow, twilight zone kinda stuff here!
Fingerprint reader after 2+ weeks of perfection suddenly doesn't recognize me. Regardless of what I do it will not acknowledge my fingerprint!
2nd option is unlock with password: Hmmm, i think I know my password, but my fingerprint has worked so well I haven't used it. Enter what I think it is, negative. 2nd option, negative. Negative, negative, negative. 
At this point I go grab my Moto 360 which is a trusted device, aka should disable password requirement. I get the 360 to connect, nada- the device is adamant about a password. It will not unlock!
Go to the car, another "trusted" zone- I get a quick connection but the device still wants the password. It refuses to unlock. 
Now I see the "unlock with google option- perfect I think. Enter my user and password- declined! 
At this point I believe that I am losing my mind, and the world is against me. It is 4:15, and I have a 4:30 call with a billion dollar company I am trying to recruit.
Reboot- clean fingerprint sensor for the 50th time. 
Try fingerprint again, fail. Connected to the moto 360 trusted device, unlock= fail! Password attempts- every known combo I have ever used= fail!
At this point, I start to focus on "unlock with google". My known user and password is not working. WTF! So I conclude that since my device is secured with 2 factor, it wants a device specific password and not my normal google password. 
Try and go to google.com on my desktop- it wants a 2 factor code from the app on my phone which is locked! HAAAAAA!
Decide to try and get a text sent instead, but I have google voice for SMS and it too is locked! Cant read the text!
I am floored at this point, and realizing I have really gotten into a bad situation. 
Finally I go and grab an ipad which is thankfully logged into google which enables me to go to the security settings on google.com and set a device specific password. I create it- and then enter the 16 digit p/w into my phone on the "unlock with google" screen. Finally, I am in!
Lock it again, fingerprint unlock works immediately!
Wow, unreal holy ****! What an ordeal!

Sad thing is it took an IPad to fix.
Posted via the Android Central App

That was a perfect storm.
Why did you have to two-factor into your Google account on your desktop? Did it automatically lock you out due to failing on the phone? Or do you typically log out of your Google account on your desktop?
Now would be a good time to either add a backup phone to authenticate with on your Google account, or go to your account's security page and print out a backup code, and keep it secure somewhere (like a safe at home, or a safety deposit box). https://support.google.com/accounts/.../1187538?hl=en

No, it was just a work computer where I am not typically logged in. 
Good advice on the printout, I will do that.

title: Keep my Moto x or 6+... Help me choose

thread.text:
I just received my Moto X and I am having a real hard time choosing which phone to keep. I bought a Galaxy S6+ fully expecting to return it when my Moto X arrived. As it turns out, it is not that simple. Below are the issues I am wrestling with:
Pros of S6+ 
1. Screen is just so much better in every scenario. 
2. Camera is better so far. 
3. Camera has more features I actually use
4. It is lighter and smaller which was a surprise
5. The fingerprint reader works great. I use it all the time
6. It is nicer looking phone (my opinion)
7. Wireless charging is something I love and I have charges everywhere I need. 
8. Samsung pay works more like apple pay which is a good thing
9. Case options
Cons of S6+
1. Touchwiz.. only in the sense that it will slow updates. Other than that, I think Samsung did an amazing job on it this year. I have been a moto x user in the past.
2. Cost. I can get the new moto x and new 360 for less than the S6+
Pros of X
1. Love the price
2. Love the custom look
3. Feels nicer in the hand
4. Faster updates
5. SD card is only a minor plus
Cons of the X
1. Camera is not as good as my iPhone or the S6+
2. Screen 
3. Limited cases
4. No fingerprint reader
5. No wireless charging
Anyone else having this struggle?? Thanks for any thoughtful input.

I think the pros/cons list speaks for itself doesn't it? I mean really, the update speed shouldn't be a major concern since the phone works great out of the box and in some cases the update can deteriorate the phone instead of make it better (cough Note 4 cough Lollipop). I had a glance at the Moto X pure/style and even though I'm a fan of the custom look, hands down the Edge+ looks better especially in gold, or silver like the one I have.

replies.text: If the price was closer it would be easy. I would love silver but I have the gold. How do you get the silver?

You never mentioned that price was a factor in your original post. I say if you can afford it then you get what you pay for. The better phone is more expensive, although we'd all be happier if phones like the Moto X / OnePlus etc would prove to be better than Samsung flagships.
I live in Australia and the Edge+ is only available here in black and white versions but after I saw the silver on youtube I knew that's what I wanted so I bought an unlocked dual sim version off ebay outright. I only buy my phones outright because I upgrade more than once a year and don't like to be locked on a contract.
Edit: sorry I just re-read and you DID mention something about the price. I guess I didn't read enough into it lol my bad.

I fixed my issue by returning the phone after three days of cell standby sucking 59% of my battery, and talking to VZW and Samsung daily. Finally, I did a factory reset, did not restore any data or load any apps and for 9 hours left the phone sitting untouched on the counter top with decent signal ( 2 bars is decent in my area). I ignored messages, checked emails on my pc, resisted the urge to pick it and check news or weather. I did not turn the screen on for nine full hours. After nine hours, I had 12% battery left and cell standby had consumed 40 times more juice than anything else on the phone. 
After this, tech support recommended return the phone. I decided to talk to Samsung first...
Please note that I said, I did not pick the phone up, I did not turn on the screen for nine hours. The Samsung rep kept insisting that because of the stellar screen, it would drain a lot of battery if I did not have screen brightness turned down to less than 40%. I told her I only had a total of 3 minutes of screen time, period. Described the situation, again. Samsung basically said that because of the huge processor I would never get more than 9 hours of use. I guess sitting on the counter looking unbelievably gorgeous is "use". I went to my corporate store, they read tech support notes refunded my money and even waived the restock fee.
This will upset some people but oh well, Samsung is on my do not buy list for a while until they stop hiring people who insist that I simply don't understand how hard my cell phone works while sitting on my kitchen counter. my old OG nexus will just have to keep on keeping on for a while,oddly also a Samsung phone, but God that phone has been great.

replies.text: It is not a wise solution. But someday I will try to disable Google Now to see the difference. I still lose more than 10% juice overnight with all kind of data connections turn off.

Go to your Location settings and check Location history, I'd turn that off, problem is that Google incorporated Location reporting (one of the biggest battery drainer on a Android) into Location history, so now, buy turning that on. It turns location reporting on, and the only thing to prevent the drain from the constant device pinging is by turning that off.
For location use Power saver mode (WiFi and cell data only), no GPS unless you need it for Google maps or any other similar apps that needs pinpoint location. Weather widgets and apps doesn't need to use your current location, just type your city or cities of choice manually and you'll save a lot of battery doing this and the above mentioned.
I always disable the Google now's "OK Google" from any screen as it consume some battery having to always being listening and I really don't use it that way, you can always leave the widget accessible and just press the mic from it and it will do the same.
Won't disabling location history prevent you from locating the phone if it is lost or stolen?

No, just when you turn off Location completely. Location History is not needed for the Location Services to work, this is just a Google Service to enable other features. Take a look at this information. Google’s Location History is Still Recording Your Every Move.
On this one will show you how it was until mid April when we had 2 separate options, Location reporting and Location History, before I had location history on but Reporting off as it was besides the Screen, the number 1 battery drainer on Android, and I frankly didn't want to be "reporting" Google all my moves, but now that they incorporated both into just one setting, then I just prefer to turn it off. Check this other link. Understanding Google's Android location tracking | Android Central

Thanks for this tip. I just made the change.
Posted via the Android Central App

title: Google play services

thread.text:
What exactly does Google Play Services do is it something that can be disabled without causing problems.
Posted via the Android Central App

That would be a huge DON'T DISABLE. Google Play Services does a lot for the OS. Like it says, it's the general service provider for what your phone does that's Google related... and since Android is Google, well... Play Store, Hangouts, GMail, Google Search, Google Location services, etc. They all need that to work.

replies.text:
Cool thanks what I thought but had to ask and learn.
Posted via the Android Central App

thread.text: Unfortunately Android does a very poor job at describing what goes on with Play Services and bundles it up into a single process that might seem like a single app is taking up a lot of your battery, when in reality is a bunch of different processes for different apps/services.

title: Who'd you buy from? Web, carrier store, electronics retailer....?? Easiest exchanges?

thread.text:
I've historically bought from Best Buy, but the version that I want (gold 32GB) is never in stock. My two local Verizon stores are pretty weak, so I try to avoid them. That leaves Verizon.com.
I'm fine with that...but I've been reading the threads here people needing to exchange their phones for various reasons, and it has made me wonder: not just who you bought yours from, but who you think makes exchanges easiest? I'm sort of thinking that that would be a local Verizon store...but no kidding, those guys just don't make me feel confident. But surely more efficient than shipping phones back and forth to some far-flung warehouse...right?
So please advise! Thanks!

What are you trying to do? Upgrade or full price?
I'm on unlimited data which means I cannot upgrade 2 of my lines. Because of this, I've been using Swappa for about 2 years now. I've bought and sold many a phone on Swappa and have had luck every time. 
As for a warranty, you're screwed if it's not an iPhone. When I had an iPhone that I purchased off Swappa last year, I immediately took it to the Apple store and paid the $99 for coverage. They didn't care where I bought the phone from as they inspected it and made sure it worked fine, then took my money. Money well spent IMO, even if I never had to use it. VZW, however, won't cover a phone not purchased from them and Sammy's program says my new Edge + isn't available to be warrantied, so I cannot break it, otherwise I get to pay for another one from Swappa.

Tmobile corporate store. They gave me no hassles about exchanging my s6e plus within the 14 day period for a new one since I was having fast charging issues with my first s6e plus.

The rep at my Best Buy was trying to talk me into the Note 5 saying the s6e+ wasn't worth it. Same phone without the stylus IMO. S6e+ is way sexier too.

replies.text:
This times one million. This is kind of a long story, but I've never experienced anything remotely like it. I'm asking you to indulge me because I'm just that way LOL...and kidding aside, I learned a lot from my shopping trip this morning.
I went into Best Buy like a lot of people, to look at the two phones side by side, and I've never had a harder full court press than I did from THREE different salespeople about how I really, really, really need to go with the Note 5 instead of the edge+.
Admittedly, this was first thing in the morning on a weekday, and the three people working the Sammy Pavilion clearly had time on their hands. I had some time on my own hands while I was getting my car worked on, so I was in no hurry. And because I had the place to myself, I didn't need to be. I was there for 20 minutes or so, and I heard from all three of the salespeople at least twice, and a couple of 'em came by at least four times -- and every single contact was to try to talk me into the Note.
I've loved my Note 3 mind you...and when I said that, all three of them responded, "Then you know how cool the pen is!!!!!!" I could practically hear the emojis coming out of their mouths. To which I replied, "Uhm, no, I don't use the pen."
At which point, each of them whipped out their pens to show me all the cool stuff I could do with my S Pen.
Soon after I arrived, a father and son arrived. I'm guessing the son was mid-40s, the dad late-60s. They both have the Note 3, except the son had his stolen last night, and he too was trying to decide between the Note 5 and the edge+. Neither father nor son ever used their S Pens.
And these guys got the same full-court press I did! Man o man, the salespeople were ALL OVER these 2 fellas. Kept showing them all the cool things they could do with the S Pen. The phrase "It's all about the S Pen. That's why you want the Note" came out of their mouths repeatedly. "You can do so much more with the Note.:
AND they kept repeating that they're selling hardly any ede plusses, because "everybody looks at them both and goes straight for the Note. They're selling like crazy."
The son actually opted for the Note 5 in the end, but half of me wonders if it was just to get these salespeople off his back. 
On the other hand, wow, amazing customer service. They took good care of me. No matter what I wanted to know, they told me. I even got a tutorial in what I could be doing with my pen. They were VERY attentive.
Until I told them that I wanted the edge+, They got icy cold, all three stopped talking to me, barely even LOOKED at me -- and bizarrely enough, were in no hurry to even take my order!!!! I it was like I'd offended them so badly they didn't even want my business. 
Oh yeah, and they never once mentioned any positive features about the edge+!!! Not a peep. It never came up until I specifically asked about it, right at the end, right before they stopped talking to me.
When told that the gold 32 wasn't in stock, I asked when they'd get it back in, one of them spat out, "We get them in every few days." In other words, I'm not going to actually look it up for you. One of them at least bothered to go through the motions and said, "Well, it's hard to tell. Maybe try calling tomorrow or the day after."
This all made me wonder if there's some kind of incentive that they get for selling the Note 5, and maybe they were mad because I was costing them money. I have no idea.
I certainly agree that the edge+ is getting more love in GENERAL. The edge and edge+ were on the front side of the Sammy Pavilion, and the Note was on the back. Much bigger signage too, no doubt about it. I see commercials for the edge+ quite regularly, and I'm pretty sure I've never seen one for a Note. Here's my theory: the edge+ looks innovative. It looks like Samsung is swinging for the fences.
The problem is that if they lead with the Note...which they've never really advertised before compared to Galaxy...it now looks like they're trying to play catch-up with Apple...even though the Note came long before the new iPhone. 
I don't know about you, but every iPerson I knew mocked me for the Note, saying it was ridiculous, garish, and impractical -- then ran over every dog and senior citizen in their path to buy the big iPhone. It's the curse of Apple's competitors -- no matter how innovative you are, you look like a derivative loser when Apple releases their thing that you had two years ago, because only Apple innovates. RIGHT?
That doesn't enter into the conversation with the edge+. People look at that and KNOW that Apple's not doing anything like that. Of course, once Apple DOES come out with something like this, then Samsung -- and you and I -- will fall back into the category of losers and wannabes.
In the meantime, though, even the Best Buy sales bots admit that edge+ is what's bringing people in the door. Why they're interested in sending those phones out into the wild to make more converts is beyond me....which is why I'm thinking that they must be getting incentives for selling the Note.
Apologies again for the length of this, but I'm still a little traumatized. LOL But the experience gave me a chance to observe this dynamic at close range, and to compare what I saw with what I heard.

title: Verizon Qi Charging Stand problems with case on my Edge +

thread.text:
I'm having some problems with my Qi Charging stand from Verizon when I have a otterbox case on my Edge +. It will charge fine but after maybe a min, it will act light I removed it and then it will connect again and charge. 
Any Ideas?

replies.text:
Welcome to the forums!
Try removing the otterbox case and see if that fixes the problem. If it does, then it's definitely the case causing interference which in turn stops the charging between the two devices. There's really no fix if this is the case, other than selecting another protective case or removing the device from the case when charging. Which will be problematic since the purpose of Qi charging is going wireless and having the convenience of being able to place the device on the charger without further hassle.

thread.text: Also, I have a Qi charger that was working great. No issues. Now after a few months it's starting to loose it's sweet spot. I find I'm having to move the phone around more to find that perfect spot and no longer able to just plop it on the charger. My point? It could be your charger too.

title: To protect screen or not?

thread.text:
I am coming from an iPhone (back to Android) and I didn't use screen protectors on my iPhone and it held up well to scratches. I am worried however that with the edge features I need one. Mainly using the face down features. 
Are you guys getting a screen protector? 
I am leaning toward yes.
Posted via the Android Central App

In all honestly screen protectors are less about the scratch resistance of the Gorilla Glass than the risk of damaging the display if it gets dropped or something falls on it. I have an number of co-workers who never used screen protectors until they dropped their phone the first time, after paying to replace it they quickly added a tempered glass screen protector. One of my co-workers has benefited greatly since his wife's iPhone 6 Plus was dropped by her, screen replaced, he dropped it, screen replaced again I told him about tempered glass (he had never heard of them) and since then he has dropped his phone 3 times and the tempered glass took the hit. The best part, Lifetime Warranty Replacements on the Tempered Glass, he has had them replaced 3 times for FREE. So $20-40 up front saved him hundreds is damaged displays.

title: What resolution is everybody recording video in?

thread.text: .... and why?

Since I don't have an 80" TV, 1024. Unless you're sitting so close to a 55" TV that you can see the individual dots in 1080, 4k isn't going to to do much as far as what you see.
If you're recording something for posterity - your baby's first steps, for instance, you might want to go to 4k, because by the time she's old enough for you to embarrass with the video, 4k will be an old technology that almost no one uses any more. (How many people still have 8mm silent film from when they were kids 60 years ago? Even when my daughter was born 40 years ago, we had sound.)

1080p for documenting throw away stuff like sending quick video to friends of a location or a detail sensitive "how to make a cake without burning the kitchen down". 
4k for important or special stuff like the magical dancing squirrel that talks French to you in the way to work that no one would believe otherwise.
Smooth motion when possible. 
Slow motion when I remember and would look great (some sport moves and fast moving skill stuff, motogp)
I have 64 gig phone and is easy to dump any amount of video that I may shoot on my phone.
I used to use micro SD cards. Pics andvids went right in. Then side sync came out and was using that on my note 4 with a USB cable. So fast (wifi works too). So i have so much space on my phone. I used to clog up my phone with old pics and video but I started looking at what was filling up my phone and do a bit of spring cleaning once in a while and all is good.
Posted via the Android Central App

I want to record "important" things in the highest resolution available...which is fine if I am going to upload it to Youtube or something...but if I want to just watch it back on my outdated 6 year old iMac it can't handle it....BUT as you mentioned this resolution will be old technology in the not too distant future and I'm sure I'll have a computer that will laugh at handling these videos.

1080p because I can use all the features and I don't own anything that supports 4K anyways
Posted via the Android Central App
4K, looks awesome on the Sony 4K TV

The video limitations are probably the ONLY complaint I have about the camera on my Edge+. Sure, there's 4K video but then you miss out on HDR, stabilization / tracking, and the ability to take photos during video. Those are some pretty steep limitations, especially the stabilization. On the other hand, I haven't had a chance to compare the stabilization between 4K and 1080p... is it really noticeable? I am a pretty shaky person when shooting video. Heck, even the 1080p/60 mode has these limitations, so I shoot mostly in 1080p/30.

title: S6 Edge+ Question! Go Easy...I'm a Newbie. ;)

thread.text:
So, I'm probably the "Greenest" Person on this Site when it comes to Android...mainly because I've just never taken the time to learn it (yes, I'm an Apple Fan, so I started with the Original iPhone and have made it as far as the 4s, before just keeping 1 phone until its death...which is Very Close)! Please don't Flame me over the iPhone part. LOL
I have a good friend that wants to buy a New S6 Edge Plus 64GB in Gold. The trouble is that he needs it to work on CDMA and GSM/LTE and to have it Unlocked for International Use. I have searched until my Brain is Bleeding and cannot seem to find any Unlocked Versions that seem to say they work for Both GSM and CDMA. I've looked at International Models that are Factory Unlocked, but no CDMA Capability. I've looked at US Models that have CDMA, but can't find a Definitive Answer on Getting One Unlocked (Especially for International Use, because of regional Locks), or GSM Capability.
Can ANYONE give me a Definitive Answer? Is this even Possible? Where do I need to look? Any Help would be Appreciated Beyond Measure! I know the iPhone 6/6 Plus have Dual Radios and Can use CDMA or GSM from the same Handset. Edge Plus seems more Elusive, so far. So Please, I Beg You...Put me out of my Misery and tell me if I'm chasing Unicorns...
Thank You SO MUCH!
Scott

Welcome to Android Central! I don't think you'll be able to find what your friend wants. CDMA is primarily used in the US, so you're probably stuck with getting the phone from Verizon, Sprint, or US Cellular. Verizon only has the gold in 32 GB, not 64 GB. Verizon doesn't carrier lock their phones any more: Device Unlocking Policy | Verizon Wireless.
Sprint also only carries the 32 GB gold S6 Edge+, but their unlock policy is a bit more involved--I don't know how many headache your friend might run into: Legal / Regulatory & Consumer Resources
US Cellular doesn't seem to have the 64 GB version, nor does it carry it in gold.
The phones should be compatible with both CDMA and GSM--see this article about the Verizon version: Samsung Galaxy S6 Edge Plus (SM-G928V) certified by FCC, partial specs leak
You friend's best bet is probably to buy the Verizon 32 GB gold version outright, then activate it on whatever network he plans to use it on. He needs to make sure that the phone's network bands are compatible with the bands that the carrier uses.

Thanks for the Reply! That's exactly what I was expecting to hear, to be honest. I have researched the "Unlocking" Policies of each company in the U.S. (The main ones, anyway), and Verizon seems to be the most logical choice. If he wants Gold, he's stuck with 32 GB and if he wants 64GB, he's stuck with Black.
Thanks again for the confirmation!
Scott
